summary: On August 23, 2005 the French Sports newspaper L'Equipe charged that Lance Armstrong used the drug EPO in 1999. Armstrong strongly denied the charge. The French sports minister, the Tour de France director and the chief executive of the USCycling said that since the tests used as a basis for the charges were inadequate no action would be taken against the cyclist. A Texas scientist attributed Armstrong's performance to his modern training approach, not EPO. A specialist in the fight against doping in sports, however, suggested that Armstrong had used a range of banned substances.    On May 23, 2005 sports newspaper L'Equip reported Armstrong illegally used erythropoietin for the 1999 Tour de France, based on urine samples examined outside World Anti-Doping Agency protocols, but linked to Armstrong by L'Equip, in violation of WADA anonymity rules. Tour Director Leblanc accepted the charge uncritically, but discipline seemed unlikely because WADA testing was impossible. The French Sports Minister agreed. USA Cycling, Miguel Indurain, and Ed Coyle defended Armstrong. Armstrong took erythropoietin during cancer treatments before 1999. An International Cycling Union investigation of 1999 drug testing is pending. Alessandro Donati suggested without evidence that Armstrong used other banned substances.    French newspaper L'Equipe reported new tests by a French laboratory on backup urine samples Lance Armstrong provided at the 1999 Tour de France tested positive for EPO. Armstrong strongly denied the charges and questioned the validity of the tests. USA Cycling, fellow cyclists, scientists and French fans have defended Armstrong. Defenders attacked the report as unethical and the laboratory results as flawed and unsound. Armstrong is suing a British newspaper for printing excerpts from a book which insinuated he had been doping. An Italian specialist believes Armstrong used other drugs, too. However, he has never been found guilty of doping.    A French newspaper accused Lance Armstrong of using the illegal performance-enhancing drug, EPO in 1999 to win his first of seven consecutive Tours. The laboratory conducting the tests couldn't confirm the samples were Armstrong's, but the newspaper said it decoded the labels from samples identifying Armstrong. Armstrong strongly denies this charge. The director of UT's Human Performance Laboratory, who studied Armstrong's physiology from 1992 to 1999, stated that Armstrong's record winning streak is explained by his years of training and a modest diet in the spring months before the Tour de France.

summary: On Sept. 9, 2005 the International Cycling Union (UCI) said no action would be taken against Armstrong. On Sept. 21 the IOC Athletes Commission and the Summer Olympic sports demanded suspension of the French laboratory that accused Armstrong, claiming that its tests were illegal. The charge was made in a letter to the World Anti-Doping Agency President, who replied that the laboratory did not appear to have broken any ethical rules. On Oct. 6 the UCI President called for an independent investigator to look into the Armstrong matter in case ongoing investigations by UCI and WADA reached different conclusions.    Armstrong sued SCA Promotions for breach of contract based on L'Equip's charges. ICU's Verbruggen refuted WADA's Pound's claims Verbruggen gave L'Equip information linking Armstrong to positive 1999 erythropoietin results. Verbruggen claimed Pound blocked ICU's investigation and made "transparently erroneous statements". The International Olympic Athletes Commission and Summer Olympic Sports both demanded WADA's lab be suspended for illegally violating WADA code. The IOC and the ICU each appointed independent investigators into all issues relating to the Tour's 1999 positive tests.    Lance Armstrong continues to vehemently deny doping charges. The IOC president called for an independent investigation into allegations he used EPO in 1999. He questioned the integrity and validity of the tests and demanded the laboratory be suspended. The International Cycling Union and the World Anti-Doping Agency both announced separate inquiries. UCI and WADA have been feuding over the case. UCI accused WADA of withholding information. WADA accused former UCI president Verbruggen of leaking documents to L'Equipe.    The International Cycling Union (ICU) gave Lance Armstrong major support in his fight against doping allegations. An ICU statement said no action would be taken against Armstrong over claims that his 1999 urine samples tested positive for EPO. The ICU found no wrongdoing and no reason to condemn him. The IOC Athletes Commission and the Summer Olympic sports (ASOIF) have demanded the French lab that tested Armstrong's urine be suspended. The World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) insists the lab broke a host of rules set down by the WADA Code.

summary: U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow's mother and husband were shot at her home in an apparent retaliation for her contempt order against Matthew Hale, a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements. Hale is currently in federal prison awaiting sentencing for previously soliciting the murder of Lefkow. Federal agents and police are investigating Hale's colleagues and looking for two men seen near Lefkow's home at the time of the murders. Evidence recovered at the scene include: shell casings, a fingerprint, footprint, and cigarette butts. Hale denies any involvement in the murders.     Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow's husband and mother were murdered in their home on February 28. They died of multiple gunshot wounds between 10:30 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. Evidence being analyzed includes broken window glass with a fingerprint, a bloody footprint, .22-caliber shell casings, a bloody mop and cigarette butts. Investigators released composite sketches of two men seen near the home on the day of the killings. A $50,000 reward is being offered for leads in the case. The prime suspect is domestic extremist Matthew Hale, convicted last year of soliciting her murder. He and his supporters deny any involvement.    Once white supremacist Matthew Hale was convicted and in jail for plotting to kill Judge Joan Lefkow, her security detail was dropped. Killers entered her house, had her husband and mother lie on the basement floor, and shot each to death. Police and FBI investigated widely but focused on Hale and his violent supporters. Evidence included a window shard with a fingerprint, a bloody mop and shoeprint, cigarette butts, and 22-caliber shell casings. Witness sightings of two white men waiting in a red Ford Escort produced composite sketches. Investigators seized communication and computer records and offered a $50,000 reward.    The husband and mother of U.S. District Judge Joan Lefkow were killed in the basement of her Chicago home on 28 February. Investigators found a bloody footprint and fingerprints butts at the scene. There are no suspects. Investigators have questioned relatives, friends, and supporters of Matthew Hale, the leader of a large white supremacist group, who was convicted last year of obstruction of justice and of ordering Lefkow's killing. They also want to question two men seen in a car illegally parked near the home that afternoon. A $50,000 reward has been offered for information in the case.

summary: The Lefkow murder investigation continues. FBI Director Mueller testified to lawmakers that the case will be solved. Bart Ross confessed to the Lefkow murders in his suicide note. Several years ago Judge Lefkow had dismissed Ross' billion dollar medical malpractice suit. DNA evidence gathered at the murder scene matched Ross' DNA. Gun shells found at the suicide location along with the note recounting details only the killer would know point to Ross as the likely killer. No evidence has been found linking Ross to the Hale supremacist group. Authorities will not close the case before ballistic results are completed.    The Lefkow murder investigation took a surprising turn when Bart Ross committed suicide at a traffic stop on March 9, leaving a handwritten confession in his car. Later that day, a local TV station receive a typed suicide letter, dated February 13, which included a hit list of judges, lawyers and doctors and a handwritten account of the Lefkow killings. Ross felt he was a medical malpractice victim and spent over a decade unsuccessfully pursuing lawsuits. Judge Lefkow, who recently ruled against Ross, was his primary target the day of the killings. DNA evidence confirm he was the killer.    Bart Ross, 57, was pulled over by police in a Milwaukee suburb for a defective taillight. Ross immediately committed suicide with a shot to his head. In his van was a letter describing how after treatment for mouth cancer left him disfigured, Judge Lefkow and others ruined his life by dismissing his medical malpractice suit. He vowed to kill them. On February 28th he hid in a Lefkow closet waiting for the judge, but her family found him first so he killed them instead. DNA from a cigarette butt in the home matched Ross's and he resembled a composite sketch.    The killer of Judge Lefkow's husband and mother, Bart Ross, killed himself on 9 March with a single shot to the head when he was stopped for a routine traffic violation. In his van was a suicide note linking him to the murders. He had pursued a decade-long malpractice suit over severe disfigurement resulting from treatment for a cancerous jaw, a suit Lefkow had dismissed a number of years ago. He wrote that she was "No. 1 to kill" because she had "finished me off." He had a hit list of 25 other judges, lawyers, and doctors.

summary: Rioting by young Muslim men broke out in a Paris suburb on the night of Oct. 27, 2005. Cars were torched, windows smashed, and policemen stoned. On successive nights the rioting spread to other parts of Paris and then to other cities. Thousands of police have been deployed to little avail. Fortunately casualties have been light. Some rioters blame the unrest on tough policing policies but it is more likely caused by frustration of young men who have no work and little hope for the future. On Nov. 8 the French government authorized local authorities to impose curfews.    On October 27, 2005 in Paris suburb Clich-sous-Bois, two youth were electrocuted and one injured hiding in a power substation from police. For 12 days riots reached nearly 300 towns and urban Paris. A Clichy-sous-Bois mosque was tear gassed. Buildings were vandalized or firebombed. Paris airport trains halted. Thousands of riot police used tear gas and rubber bullets. A woman was torched. A beaten man died. Over 30 police and firemen were injured, two shot. Nationwide, the nights of November 4 - 7 saw 750, 1,295, 1,408, and 1,173 torched vehicles; 200, 312, 395, and 330 arrests. Bloggers incited violence.    Riots erupted after the accidental electrocution deaths of two youths hiding from police they mistakenly thought were pursuing them. The incident sparked an ever-escalating 12 nights of violence which spread through Paris suburbs and into the city. Rioters torched hundreds of cars nightly, burned and vandalized buildings, injured dozens of police officers and firefighters, set a handicapped woman afire and beat a man to death. French officials appealed for calm and eventually imposed curfews to restore order. The rioters are French-Arab and French-African young men, frustrated by economic misery and racial discrimination and stigmatized by a new tough anti-crime initiative.    Riots have raged for a dozen days in the Paris northern suburb Clichy-sous-Bois. Rioters, mostly young Muslim men whose families are from former French African colonies, have burned hundreds of cars and attacked firefighters and policemen. Police have made hundreds of arrests. The riots started after two teenagers were electrocuted when they scaled an electrical relay station wall while fleeing police and touched a transformer. Tough anti-crime policies of Interior Minister Nicholas Sarkozy fueled the riots. A man died after a beating and a woman was badly burned when exiting a bus. Police and firefighters have sustained minor injuries.

summary: On the night of Nov. 9, 2005 the level of violence throughout France showed the first signs of abating. More than 11,500 police and gendarmes in 300 cities and towns had been mobilized. Residents, police and firefighters suffered one death and more than 115 injuries. More than 7500 vehicles were torched. Although the riots were ignited by the accidental electrocution death of two teenagers, President Chirac acknowledged that France must confront inequalities and discrimination among its African and Muslim minorities that fueled the unrest. On Nov. 14 emergency powers were extended for three months.    After long police absence, Sarkozy's October 19 declaration of "war without mercy" on violent suburbs fueled the riots starting October 27. On November 8, France declared a state of emergency, and offered social assistance. By November 11, 118 residents, police, firefighters, and foreign journalists were injured, with $US 235 million total damage. By November 13, torched vehicles exceeded 8,000 and arrests exceeded 2,200. Vehicle torchings and arrests, respectively, November 1 - 12 were: 180/34, ?/?, 517/78, 897/250, 1300/349, 1408/395, 1173/330, 617/?, 482/?, 325/?, 384/162, 315/161. (Before the riots, 3,500 vehicles burned monthly nationwide.) France extended emergency powers on November 14.    With a state of emergency declaration, overnight curfews, and a public meetings ban, violent riots around Paris and throughout France steadily abated. The situation markedly improved by the 18th night. The French cabinet extended emergency police powers for three months to ensure an end to the riots. Some 300 towns and cities were affected and around 11,500 anti-riot forces were mobilized. Damages and casualties were considerable. Over 115 citizens, police officers and firefighters were injured, as were three foreign reporters. A rioter lost a hand throwing a Molotov cocktail. Over 7,500 vehicles were torched and dozens of buildings destroyed.    Rioting and unrest spread to some 300 areas across France. The government declared a state of emergency but left it to local authorities to enact curfews or other measures. Many areas did impose curfews but Paris only banned public meetings. Police were mobilized and made hundreds of arrests. Most rioters are young Arab and black residents who complain of economic misery and discrimination. They burned hundreds of vehicles and other acts of arson. President Chirac acknowledged that France must confront the inequalities and discrimination that fueled the unrest. For years, police had warned that immigrant-dominated slums were about to explode.

summary: A Russian mini-submarine containing 7 submariners became trapped for 3 days on the sea floor in eastern Russia. The submarine was entangled in fishing nets and/or a coastal monitoring system antenna. Russian rescue attempts to free and raise the submarine were unsuccessful. Russia requested international help. Japan, Britain and the U.S. responded with rescue equipment. The British Navy used a robotic vehicle to free the submarine which then surfaced. The crew were in satisfactory condition and taken for medical examination. Russia's naval equipment has not been upgraded as promised by Putin following the Kursk submarine tragedy.    On Aug. 4, 2005 the Russian navy, working desperately to disengage a small military submarine with seven crew snagged by underwater cables at a depth of 625 feet off the Kamchatka peninsula, called for international help. Japan dispatched four vessels, Britain's Royal Navy sent a submersible Super Scorpio unmanned robotic vehicle and the U. S. Pacific fleet sent two vehicles similar to the British. Estimates varied as to how much oxygen remained for the entrapped crewmen. The British vehicle arrived first and on Aug. 7 the submarine was cut loose and the crewmen were found all alive.    For nearly three days, a Russian mini-submarine was trapped about 600 feet below the surface of the Beryozovaya Bay. The AS-28 became snarled in the cables of an undersea coastal monitoring system. Throughout the ordeal, there were varying estimates of the remaining oxygen supply. When Russian attempts to tow the sub to shallower water failed, they sent out an urgent call for international help. Japan, Britain and the US all dispatched vessels to aid the rescue efforts. A British Super Scorpio robotic underwater vehicle succeeded in freeing the mini-sub. All seven sailors aboard were rescued in satisfactory condition.    A small Russian submarine with seven crew members was trapped on the seabed off the Kamchatka Peninsula late on 4 August. The Russians tried desperately to pull the sub to shallower waters but those efforts failed. They sought international assistance. Japan sent four naval vessels, the U.S. sent three underwater vehicles, but the British were the first to arrive, with remote control submersibles. They cut away the net or undersea cables trapping the sub, enabling it to rise to the surface after almost three days at the bottom. All seven crew members were alive and well.

summary: Criticism by Russian authorities of their Navy arose quickly following the rescue. Accident notification was delayed as in the Kursk tragedy. Putin ordered an investigation. Russian rescuers damaged their underwater robotic vehicle during the rescue attempt making it inoperable. When the British rescue vehicle arrived by air there was no equipment to unload it. Russia is considering purchasing a robotic Scorpio or Panther for underwater rescue operations. Adm. Kuroyedov, head of the Russian Navy, was fired and replaced by Adm. Masorin. Masorin has been charged with improving the Navy. Operation errors by the crew were cited as causing the accident.    Following recovery of the submarine, Russian authorities praised the international rescue effort and thanked Britain, the U.S. and Japan, but questions were soon raised as to why their navy did not have the proper equipment for such an operation. Updated equipment was soon purchased. President Putin ordered an investigation of the accident. On Sept. 4 Putin fired the head of the navy. On Sept 6 the defense minister announced that the submarine accident was a result of outrageous violations of the instructions by senior officials of the Russian Pacific Fleet and that the crew had made errors.    An investigation uncovered violations of instructions and errors in operating the mini-sub that contributed to the recent accident. Prosecutors accused a naval officer of negligence for damaging Russia's own Venom rescue vehicle, thereby necessitating international assistance. Newspapers criticized the navy for waiting over a day before revealing information about the accident. There are conflicting reports about whether the sub was caught in cables or fishing nets. The Russian navy is considering buying at least one Scorpio and possibly a newer model Panther rescue vehicle. The head of the Russian navy was fired, probably in part because of the accident.    Putin ordered the Defense Minister to launch an investigation. The head of the Navy was fired. A Navy captain was accused of damaging a Russian under-water remote-controlled vehicle in rescue attempts. Five British, one Japanese, and two Americans were given state awards. The seven crew members were given awards for bravery, but later accused of violating operating procedures and causing the sub's entanglement. The Russian navy was considering buying one or two submersible rescue vessels. The rescue cost Russia an estimated $1.5 million. Britain, the U.S., and Japan did not charge Russia for their assistance.

summary: During the morning rush hour on July 7, terrorists exploded bombs on three London subway trains and a double-decker bus, killing at least 52 and injuring 700. A group called Secret al-Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility. The attacks were timed to coincide with the G-8 summit meeting at Gleneagles, Scotland. Forensic evidence indicates that each bomb contained less than 10 pounds of possibly military-grade high explosives, and all were made by a single bomb maker. There is not yet evidence as to whether suicide bombers were involved. Police are close to identifying someone responsible for the bus attack.    Four coordinated bombings struck central London on July 7, three in subway cars and one on a bus. The blasts killed 52 persons and sent 350 to hospitals where 22 remain critical. An additional 350 were treated for light injuries. Hot, dusty conditions in subway tunnels hampered rescue operations. PM Tony Blair returned to London from the Group of Eight meeting in Scotland after the bombings. Police said each bomb contained less than ten pounds of military-grade explosives and did not rule out suicide bombers as responsible. A group called Secret al-Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility.    Four coordinated bombs exploded in central London during morning rush hour on July 7th, coinciding with the G8 summit in Scotland. About 700 were injured and 52 killed. Three bombs were on subway trains and one on a bus. Each was small enough to fit in a rucksack. The Secret al-Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility, to avenge British involvement in wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. No evidence arose of suicide bombers. Investigators viewed video by cameras on streets and subway platforms around London. Londoners took the terrorist attacks in stride, used to IRA bombs and the WWII blitz.    Four coordinated terrorist attacks occurred in London during the morning rush hour on Thursday 7 July. Bombs exploded on three subway trains and one double-decker bus. The bombs all contained similar components: military-grade explosives under 10 pounds, small enough to fit into a backpack. The explosions killed at least 52 people and injured more than 700. Investigations at the tunnel site were slow, hampered by very high heat, asbestos dust, and twisted metal. Investigators do not know how many suspects they are looking for, but reported progress toward identifying one of the bombers.

summary: The July 7 London bombing death toll is now 56, including four suicide bombers. Police identified the four and know details of their final movements. All were British of Pakistani origin. Police raided five premises in Leeds and recovered a car they expect will yield evidence. Authorities were tipped off when one bomber's mother called a help line to report him missing. ABC News reported that the alleged bomb maker behind the London attacks was arrested in Egypt. Authorities fear that a number of recent arson attacks on mosques in England may have been retaliation for the bombings.    The death toll rose to 56 and 44 victims of the bombings remain in hospitals, nine in intensive care. Four of those dead were suicide bombers who carried out the bombings. Police identified three of the bombers by name and said that all four were British of Pakistani origin. Police were able to trace the movements on CCTV of the bombers from their arrival at a carpark until just before the explosions. Armed with warrants, police raided five premises in Leeds; home to a large Muslim population of south Asian origin.    The four bombers were British of Pakistani origin and were among the 56 killed. The bombers left their homes in West Yorkshire and drove a rented a car to Luton, NW of London, where they met a fourth accomplice. Closed circuit television at King's Cross caught them all chatting, then they split up. The mother of one reported him missing after the blasts, leading to identifications and raids on five premises in Leeds, which has a large Moslem population. The alleged bomb-builder was arrested in Egypt. After the bombings, several arson attacks took place on mosques in northwest England.    As of 20 July, the death toll stood at 56, with all victims identified. Police had finished their investigations on site and moved one subway car from the underground tunnel to a police compound for further investigation.  The suspected bombers, all four of whom were killed in the explosions, were Islamic extremists. British of Pakistani origin, the four were captured on closed ciruit TV at King's Cross soon before the bomings. An additional suspect was said to have been arrested in Cairo, Egypt, on 15 July.

summary: Syria's withdrawal of forces from Lebanon, required by UN Resolution 1559, Sept. 2, 2004, was not satisfied by Syria's proposal on Feb. 24, 2005 to pull back into eastern Lebanon. The U.N. Chief, supported by Egypt, Saudi Arabia, the U.S., France and Russia, called for full withdrawal. On March 5 the Syrian President promised pullback to the border. A top UN envoy on March 12 demanded a full withdrawal by April 30, a position supported by the European Union. By April 26 withdrawal was under way and the UN had sent a team to verify whether it was complete.    UN Security Council Resolution 1559 mandated withdrawal of "foreign forces" (Syria's troops and intelligence agents) from Lebanon. After the February 14, 2005 assassination of former Lebanon Prime Minister Hariri, Anon told Syria to withdraw before April, threatening sanctions. Egypt and Saudi Arabia asked Syria to withdraw by April 30, under the 1989 Taif Accord. Lebanon's pro-Syria government resigned March 1. On March 12 Anon sent envoy Roed-Larsen to Syria with an ultimatum. Syria pledged to withdraw all troops. EU Foreign Ministers asked Syria to rapidly implement its pledge.     The February assassination of former Lebanon Prime Minister Hariri put Syria under renewed pressure from the international community to abide by U.N. Security Council Resolution 1559 and withdraw its troops from Lebanon. The US, France and other European Union nations urged Syria to comply. Egypt and Saudi Arabia encouraged Syria to withdraw its troops by the U.N. deadline of April 30. Faced with a U.N. ultimatum, on April 3 Syria pledged to remove all troops and intelligence agents by April 30. The U.N. sent a team of inspectors to verify whether the withdrawal was complete at the end of April.    The killing of Lebanon's former PM Rafiq Hariri renewed calls for Syria to abide by UN Security Council Resolution 1559 and end its domination of Lebanon. Nine council members voted for the resolution, six abstained. Egypt and Saudi Arabia are trying to persuade Syria to accept a timetable for withdrawal of its troops. The US and France have been leading calls for Syria's withdrawal. The European Union called for a precise timetable for withdrawal. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan said that withdrawal must be handled with care. Under mounting pressure, Syria has withdrawn 4,000 of its 14,000 troops.

summary: On May 5 UN Chief Kofi Anan announced that the UN team had verified that all Syrian troops and intelligence officials had left Lebanon, but it was reported that the team could not be certain about the intelligence operatives. There were reports that some remained with a hit list of planned assassinations. Syria denied the accusations. The UN envoy had "constructive and helpful" talks with the Syrian president on June 12. One June 23, as another UN verification team investigated, US officials expressed certainty that Syrian military intelligence operatives remained in Lebanon.    By May 23, 2005, a UN team verified the pullout of all Syrian troops and intelligence agents from Lebanon. In June, President Bush warned Syria to withdraw its remaining intelligence agents in Lebanon. Syria denied having any intelligence agents in Lebanon. The UN verification mission went back to Lebanon to ascertain the facts. The UN said it was encouraged by talks with Syria's President regarding evidence from several countries that Syrian intelligence agents were still in Lebanon. Egypt and Saudi Arabia discussed the Syria-Lebanon situation. The U.S. reiterated its certainty that Syrian intelligence agents remained in Lebanon.    Although a U.N. team verified the withdrawal of all Syrian troops from Lebanon on April 26, the US and Lebanese opposition leaders insisted that Syrian intelligence agents remained in Lebanon. The killing of a prominent anti-Syrian journalist aroused suspicions that Syria had a hit list targeting opposition leaders. Syria rejected all accusations. US President Bush issued a new warning to Syria to withdraw intelligence forces. The   U.N. was encouraged by talks with Syria on the Security Council call for Syria to end its involvement in Lebanon. A U.N. verification team was sent to Lebanon by late June to investigate.    A UN team verified the withdrawal of all Syrian troops and intelligence officials from Lebanon after a 29-year presence. International pressure following the assassination of Raafik Hariri was more of a factor leading to the withdrawal than the UN resolution. A Lebanese Druse leader claimed that Syrian military intelligence was still operating in Lebanon and feared more assassinations after a bombing killed an anti-Syrian journalist. These reports caused US President Bush to warn Syria to withdraw its forces from Lebanon. Syria claimed that every troop and agent had left Lebanon. The UN ordered a verification mission back to Lebanon.

summary: The Ukrainian presidential election race to replace President Kuchma is close and competitive. Viktor Yushchenko, former Prime Minister and leader of the anti-Kuchma opposition has a small lead over Viktor Yanukovich, current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter. Yushchenko became dangerously ill during the campaign claiming an assassination attempt. No evidence of poisoning has been found by Ukrainian or U.S. investigations. Yushchenko won the first vote but Yanukovich was declared President after a disputed runoff vote. Yushchenko demanded the results be annulled. Yanukovich offered Yushchenko the prime ministry but Yushchenko refused and called for both candidates to withdraw from the race.    In Ukraine's 2004 presidential campaign, pro-western candidate Yushchenko claimed he was poisoned by supporters of pro-Russian candidate, current Prime Minister Yanukovich. International observers alleged election violations. Yanukovich moved the Kiev Liberation Day military parade to October 29, raising fears of a military crackdown or canceled elections. State media denied Yushchenko any coverage. Students and public employees were pressured to vote for Yanukovich. Yanukovich raised pensions before the elections. On October 31, Yushchenko got 39.82%, Yanukovich 39.32%. An emergency Parliament meeting without a quorum reversed Yanukovich's November 21 victory. A healthier Yushchenko proposed new elections. Yanukovich offered Yushchenko the Prime Ministry.    Ukraine's October 31 presidential elections reduced the candidates from 24 to two, pro-Moscow Viktor Yanukovich and pro-west Viktor Yushchenko. The November 21 runoff election results are being disputed. Yushchenko is claiming Yanukovich's victory is the result of an illegal electoral commission decision and is demanding they be annulled. While campaigning, Yushchenko was struck by a mysterious illness in September and spent most of the month in an Austrian hospital. He and his supporters believe he was poisoned by political rivals. Doctors are still examining blood and other samples to determine the cause. They expect him to make a full recovery.    Ukrainian presidential elections were extremely close between the two leading candidates, pro-West Yushchenko and pro-Russia Yanukovich. Runoff elections on 21 November resulted in a standoff, with Yushchenko refusing to recognize Yanukovich as President and calling for new elections, and with Yanukovich saying that he would appoint Yushchenko Prime Minister. In September Yushchenko was treated in Vienna for a mysterious illness which paralyzed and scarred part of his face. Supporters claimed that the illness, which occurred after a meeting with the former head of the KGB, was an assassination attempt. Doctors said that they did not know the cause.

summary: Specialists in several countries confirmed that Viktor Yushchenko was deliberately poisoned with pure TCDD, a lethal form of dioxin which causes disfigurement and long term health issues. The poisoning investigation is ongoing. The earlier disputed presidential election was declared fraudulent and invalid by the Supreme Court. A repeat election was mandated. Foreign observers will help secure an honest election. Yushchenko was elected president of the Ukraine with 51.99 percent of the vote. As he took the oath of office Yushchenko vowed to improve economic conditions in the Ukraine. Viktor Yanukovych vowed to appeal the election results to the Supreme Court.    The Ukraine Supreme Court invalidated the November 21 election, due to election fraud. Yushchenko's ingested poison was identified as pure TCDD, a rare highly toxic form of Dioxin. Yushchenko deferred criminal investigations until after the repeat election December 26. Parliament failed to pass Yuschenko's election reforms, but the Constitutional Court ruled for expanded home voting, which helped Yushchenko. Yushchenko supporters pushed for Yanukovich's resignation; instead he took a leave of absence to run his campaign. The dual U.S.-Ukraine citizen Yushchenko won the Presidency 51.99% to 44.20% for Yanukovich. Yanukovich said he would appeal to the Supreme Court, without much hope.    In December, doctors determined conclusively that Yushchenko was deliberately poisoned with the most lethal form of dioxin. Prosecutors reopened a criminal investigation into his attempted murder. Yushchenko was sure that Ukrainian authorities were responsible. He fell ill on September 6, after having food and drinks with the head of the Security Service of Ukraine and others. The Ukraine Supreme Court overturned the November runoff election results due to fraud, and Parliament enacted new anti-fraud election reforms in December. Yushchenko won a repeat runoff on December 26 and took office in January, his face still disfigured by the poison.    Yushchenko was sworn in as President of Ukraine on Sunday 23 January. In a third round of voting on 26 December, Yushchenko won 51.99% of the vote to Yanukovich's 44.20%. The Supreme Court had annulled the results of the second round of voting because of election fraud. That decision followed 17 days of massive popular protests called the "Orange Revolution" after Yushchenko's campaign color. Doctors confirmed that Yushchenko had been deliberately poisoned with TCDD, the most lethal form of dioxin. Blood tests revealed levels of dioxin "more than 1000 times" normal. Yushchenko will need treatment for months if not years.

summary: New drug SR-13668 curbs AKT retroviral oncogene proteins for breast cancer. SR-16158 also treats breast cancer. The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences' Sisters Study for breast cancer compares shared genes. Arimidex and Aromasin appear to sharply reduce breast cancer occurrence or metastasis. Oleic acid dramatically cuts expression of breast cancer precursor gene Her-2/neu and amplifies Herceptin. DNA repair deficiency strongly associates with susceptibility to breast cancer. Hypothyroidism apparently lessens chances of developing aggressive forms of breast cancer. Modern radiation therapy likely does not increase heart disease risk. Oral contraceptives likely do not increase the risk of BRAC1-associated breast cancer.    The National Health Research Institute and a pharmaceutical company are testing two medications that can treat breast cancer. One drug can curb a protein active in cancer patients and the other is less likely to trigger cardiovascular disease. A new U.S. Sister Study will investigate genetic and environmental causes of breast cancer. A new drug, aromatase inhibitor, appears to sharply reduce the chances of developing cancer in the other breast. Researchers say that olive oil may help fight breast cancer. Oral contraceptives may reduce the risk of breast cancer in high-risk groups.     Developmental drug SR-13668 curbs the oncogene protein AKT, prevalent in cancer patients; and SR-16158 reduces breast cancer patient heart disease risk. Aromatase inhibitors lessen breast cancer recurrence with fewer side effects than tamoxifen. Radiation therapy no longer carries heart disease risk. Olive oil suppresses oncogene Her-2/neu and boosts effectiveness of antibody Herceptin. Hypothyroidism and oral contraceptives reduce breast cancer risk. Sisters are being studied to investigate environmental and genetic affects on cancer risk. Deficiency in cell DNA repair-ability accelerates genetic changes leading to cancer. Protein markers in genes help predict cancer recurrence. Ductal lavage proved unreliable for detecting early cancer.    An international group is studying an aromatose inhibitor, which may replace tamoxifin. And a Taiwanese-U.S. cooperative effort is developing a new breast-cancer drug. NIH has undertaken a study of sisters to find genetic and environmental causes of the disease. Other studies are looking into the effects and effectiveness of oral contraceptives, an underactive thyroid, olive oil, a cell's ability to repair DNA, and the flushing of milk ducts. A new Dutch diagnostic tool could help some breast-cancer patients avoid unnecessary treatment. And advances in technology and techniques have now made radiation safe for breast-cancer patients.

summary: Herceptin reduced HER2-positive gene-associated breast cancer recurrences 52 percent. Avastin proved effective against breast cancer. Low-grade ductal carcinoma in situ becomes invasive cancer in 40 percent of patients over 40 years. Combined chemotherapy and hormone therapy cut death in half within 15 years from recurring breast cancer. Consuming 33.3 fat grams daily reduces breast cancer recurrence 30% over five years. Exercise increases breast cancer survival 50%. Low melatonin levels in night-time workers increased breast cancer. Benign "proliferative" lesions correlate with later breast cancer. At 65 and older, early smaller localized tumors accounted for 96% of survival improvement; 38% under 50.    The drug Herceptin will soon be added to chemotherapy as a standard part of post surgical treatment for some breast cancer patients. Scientists reported that breast cancer patients who follow diets low in fat might reduce the chance that their tumors will return. A study showed that walking for three to five hours per week reduced the risk of death by 50 percent. Another study examining the role of childhood diet plays in breast cancer found an association between eating French fries regularly during the preschool years and developing breast cancer as an adult.    Risk of dying from breast cancer fell because drugs prevent recurrence and earlier-detected tumors are smaller. Herceptin halves risk of recurrence in women with tumors high in protein HER2. A low-fat diet and exercise may reduce chances of recurrence. Only removing the lymph node nearest a cancer is less invasive and accurately detects whether cancer has spread. Ductal carcinoma in situ has various grades, can be mistaken as benign, and can take 40 years to develop. Night shift workers, women with benign breast lesions, and girls who frequently ate French fries as preschoolers have a higher risk of breast cancer.     Breast cancer survival rates have improved because of better screening, leading to detection of smaller tumors when the cancer is still localized. There are two new drugs for breast cancer - herceptin and avastin. Scientists see a link between benign breast cancer lesions and later cancer. Studies have shown that both low-fat diets and exercise can increase survival rates for  breast cancer patients. But eating french fries in childhood can lead to cancer in adulthood. Night workers seem to have a higher incidence of breast cancer, indicating that there may be a relationship between tumor developent and exposure to light.

summary: In response to a call from the Institute of Medicine for a program against childhood obesity, there has been some action. One children's TV network introduced a Saturday afternoon message encouraging children to go out and play. Some schools have expanded physical education programs, yanked junk foods from vending machines and reduced fat in cafeteria food. At least one YMCA has introduced a fitness room designed for pre-teens. Congress has considered legislation to control advertising to children and Kraft Foods promised to stop TV advertising of certain products considered unhealthy to children under 12.    To combat childhood obesity in the US, schools are removing unhealthy food from vending machines, reducing the fat in lunches, and requiring more physical education. New Hampshire is instituting twice-yearly weigh-ins for students. Children's hospitals have weight management programs and a YMCA has a kid-friendly fitness room. Efforts are being made to regulate advertising to young children. Manufacturers offer cereals low in sugar and salt with more vitamins and whole grains. US Cabinet secretaries and children's television networks are promoting healthier lifestyles for children. In New Zealand, schools added a mandatory extra hour of physical activity for students every week.    Scientists say reversing childhood obesity requires wide-ranging efforts. Less time should be spent in front of the computer and television. Schools should remove junk food from vending machines and reduce the fat in cafeteria lunches. Experts recommend reducing sugar consumption. Changes need to be made in food labeling and advertising as well as more school and community recreational facilities and physical education programs. Trainers can help kids who don't enjoy organized sports or who are embarrassed doing active things with fitter kids.      Measures to fight childhood obesity include less time at the TV and computer, changes in food labeling and advertising, more school and community physical education programs and education to help children make better choices. The children's network Nickelodeon is encouraging children to go outside and play. They have also awarded grants to schools to expand physical play. Kraft  will stop TV ads of products unhealthy for children. New Zealand has ordered schools to ensure children take extra physical education. Schools in New Hampshire and Rhode Island have removed junk food and reduced fat in cafeteria lunches.

summary: On May 3, 2005 former President Bill Clinton announced a partnership of the American Heart Association with the food and restaurant industry to increase physical activity and nutrition at schools nationwide. Other action against childhood obesity followed in August and September as the American Beverage Association agreed to limit distribution of high caloric beverages in schools and Kraft unveiled new whole grain versions of some of the most popular cookies. It was announced in Bangkok, Thailand that fresh fruits, fruit juices and fresh milk would replace sweet and fatty foods in 433 schools across the city.    Former president Clinton launched a 10-year initiative to combat childhood obesity. The initiative, a partnership with the American Heart Association, will include working with the food and restaurant industry to promote change, increasing physical activity and improved nutrition at schools nationwide. School systems are now limiting the kinds of drinks sold to children and requiring more fruits and vegetables in school meals. McDonald's has made a major marketing shift toward promoting healthier eating habits. Kraft Foods has developed whole-grain versions of two of its popular cookies. Abroad, schools in Bangkok, Thailand are banning sugary and fatty foods and drinks.    Dr. George Bray, founding president of the North American Association for the Study of Obesity, warns that high-fructose corn syrup is a strong culprit behind childhood obesity. Bray suggests that childhood obesity can be prevented by getting more sleep, decreasing sedentary activities, drinking more milk (calcium controls weight), thinking portion control and eating breakfast. An Institute of Medicine report found compelling evidence encouraging the food industry to change the nature of foods being marketed to children. Former US president Bill Clinton announced a 10-year initiative to combat childhood obesity.    Illinois is now the only state that requires daily physical activity for public school students but Texas is proposing bills to require that. Former President Clinton his partnered with the American Heart Association to promote physical activity at schools nationwide. Many schools are limiting the kinds of drinks sold to children. California has taken the lead in purging soda and unhealthy snacks from schools. McDonalds's has made a major shift in marketing that could help redefine fast food. Kraft now produces a healthier cookie made with whole grains and containing zero grams of trans fats.

summary: Investigations of lobbyist Jack Abramoff and his partner Michael Scanlon by the Senate Indian Affairs Committee in 2004 resulted in other investigations. The pair's lobbying for Indian tribes and Pacific islanders was shown to have benefitted the lobbyists and political associates while bilking the clients of millions of dollars. The House majority leader and a congressman were implicated. On Nov. 18, 2005 Michael Scanlon was charged with fraud and scheduled to go to court on a conspiracy count contained in a criminal information, typically a prelude to pleading guilty and giving full cooperation with government investigators.    Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff and his associate Michael Scanlon are at the center of a growing corruption scandal. The investigation began with allegations of fraud in dealings with a number of American Indian tribes, but widened to include golf junkets and dealings in the Northern Marianas. The scandal has focused attention on a number of members of Congress and their associates, including House Majority Leader Tom DeLay of Texas and Rep. Robert Ney of Ohio. Abramoff has been arrested on fraud charges stemming from a Florida deal. Scanlon is expected to plead guilty to charges and cooperate with government investigators.    The Senate Indian Affairs Committee charged Jack Abramoff, a GOP lobbyist and fund-raiser, with running a crude extortion racket that has bilked tribes out of millions of dollars. House Majority Leader Tom DeLay, additional congressmen and House aides are under an ethics investigation resulting from their connections with Abramoff. His activities in the Northern Marianas are also being investigated. Abramoff has been indicated in federal court on six counts of fraud and conspiracy and his partner, Michael Scanlon, was charged with defrauding Indian tribes of millions of dollars.     Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff is being investigated in connection with manipulating elections and extorting lobbying fees of $66 million from six Indian tribes related to protecting gaming franchises, and $9 million from the Northern Mariana Islands related to the textile industry. Investigations also involve Abramoff's purchase of a gambling cruise ship company and arranging unreported golf junkets to Scotland. Abramoff invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Senate hearing. Also implicated are Republican Majority Leader Tom DeLay, his former aide Michael Scanlon, Ralph Reed, Representative Robert W. Ney, and David Safavian. Safavian was indicted in connection with a golf trip.

summary: Scanlon pleaded guilty to conspiring to bribe a congressman and other public officials. His help was expected to be crucial in the Justice Department's wide-ranging Abramoff investigations. On Dec. 28, 2005 the Justice Department was urgently pressing Abramoff to settle fraud and bribery allegations as the investigation continued. A court date was set for Jan. 9, 2006 as Senate and criminal investigations continued. On Jan. 3 Abramoff pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate. He agreed to provide evidence and testimony in the Justice Department's probe of corruption in Congress and executive branch agencies.    Michael Scanlon pleaded guilty to conspiring to bribe public officials and agreed to pay back over $19 million to Indian tribal clients. His possible 5-year prison sentence could be reduced should he cooperate with prosecutors. Abramoff pleaded guilty to federal conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion charges and agreed to cooperate with investigators. He did not identify officials by name. The next day he pleaded guilty to fraud and conspiracy in Florida. Panicked lawmakers, including President Bush, rushed to distance themselves from Abramoff by returning campaign money he gave them. The money is being returned or redirected to charities.    Abramoff pleaded guilty to conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion and agreed to cooperate with federal officials investing political corruption. Abramoff is also facing trial on fraud charges in Florida connected with purchasing a casino cruise chip company. In his plea agreement, Abramoff committed to making 25 million in restitution to his victims and paying 1.2 million to the IRS for tax evasion. His prison sentence could be lowered depending on assistance he provides in the corruption investigation of as many as 20 members of Congress or top congressional aides.    Abramoff's extensive corruption schemes are the subject of a Senate probe and criminal investigations by the Department of Justice and Florida prosecutors. Investigators are looking at congressmen, aides, government officials, and lobbyists, including Rep. John Doolittle, Stephen Griles, and Tony Rudy, and will follow the case wherever it leads. Scanlon pled guilty to bribery and agreed to make restitution to tribes. His help would be crucial to the Abramoff investigation. Abramoff pled guilty to conspiracy, fraud, and tax evasion and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. Co-defendant Adam Kidan agreed to testify against Abramoff regarding fraud in a ship company purchase.

summary: Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama is the most costly natural disaster in U.S. history. Initial insurance industry losses are estimated to be $20 billion. The Federal Emergency Management Agency expenses to date are almost $3 billion. The revised insurance losses estimate may be as high as $50 billion primarily due to damage of offshore energy sites. A Bush-Clinton Katrina Fund led by the former U.S. Presidents is accepting international donations. Qatar and Uganda have donated $100 million and $200,000 respectively. The current death count in the region is 126.    When Hurricane Katrina hit Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama on August 29, 2005 rescue crews worked frantically to save hundreds of people trapped by floodwaters. By September 8, the US death toll had reached 118. There was one reported death in Guatemala. FEMA's Katrina disaster response efforts cost $US 2.87 million as of September 6, 2005. By September 12, Swiss Reinsurance Company, estimated $US 40 billion global insured losses in the United States from Hurricane Katrina. The Emir of Qatar donated $US 100 million for US victims of Katrina. Uganda pledged $US 200,000 toward Katrina relief and rebuilding in the US.    Hurricane Katrina, one of the worst natural disasters, hit the southern part of the US on August 29, 2005. The official death toll has risen to 118. Federal Emergency Management Agency officials indicate that their costs are 2.8 billion dollars so far. Qatar donated 100 million dollars to the victims and the Ugandan government pledged 200,000 dollars toward relief and rebuilding efforts. This hurricane could cost the world's insurers up to 50 billion dollars as forecast by the British company Brit Insurance.     Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast on 29 August. By 9 September the official death toll had reached 118, including one Guatemalan woman who lived in New Orleans. Fifty other Guatemalans were missing. FEMA's mission expenses were close to $3 billion as of 6 September. Insurers, inclduing Lloyd's and Brit Insurance, estimated that their costs would reach $50 billion. Damage included offshore energy installations, as well as property damage and business interruption. Qatar was donating $100 million for the victims of the hurricane. Uganda had pladged $200,000 for relief and rebuilding.

summary: In addition to the current high death toll of 1,121 victims, the severe economic impacts are being assessed. Petroleum and chemicals produced in the Gulf region were sharply reduced as was oil and natural gas extraction. The 0.1% rise was extremely below economic forecasts. Farming losses are expected to be $900 million. Part of the economic impact of Katrina is the unemployment rate in Louisiana which has risen to 11.5%. The U.S. House of Representatives unanimously passed a $6.1 billion tax assistance package for people and businesses displaced due to Katrina and sent it to the U.S. Senate for consideration.    By September 27, 2005 US Katrina deaths reached 1,121. Rescuers searched for victims as successor Hurricane Rita struck. By September 14 Brit Insurance forecast $US 50 billion global insurance losses. Gulf of Mexico oil and natural gas extraction dropped sharply. Refineries and chemical plants faltered. US Agriculture lost $US 900 million. In September Louisiana unemployment was 11.5%, from August's 5.7%. Turkey gave $US 1.5 million to the US Red Cross for Katrina relief and $US 1 million in humanitarian supplies. Bosnia's Red Cross gave money. On September 21, the US House passed $US 6.1 billion in Katrina recovery tax breaks.    The death toll from Hurricane Katrina surpassed 1,100. Turkey has allocated 2.5 million dollars for victims and the Bosnian Red Cross announced that is has started raising money for victims, as well. The US House of Representatives approved tax breaks for victims. The hurricane caused job losses in Louisiana sending its unemployment rate soaring to 11.5 percent. Agricultural losses are expected to reach an estimated 900 million dollars and US industrial output has been depressed by Katrina with severe cut backs in production of petroleum and chemicals.     As of 29 September, Katrina's death toll had reached 1121 including 885 in Louisiana and 200 in Mississippi. The economic impact was massive. The global insurance industry was predicting costs of $40-$50 billion. Agricultural losses were estimated at $900 million. Louisiana's unemployment rate soared to 11.5%. And U.S. industrial output rose only slightly because of cuts in the production of petroleum and chemicals in the Gulf region. 118 countries sent aid, including $2.5 million from Turkey. The U.S. Congress was expected to approve tax breaks of $6.1 billion for people and businesses.

summary: Martha Stewart reported to a federal prison in Alderson, West Virginia on Oct. 8, 2004 to serve a five-month sentence. She is very busy. Being deluged with letters, she spends up to three hours/night at a prison typewriter. She has some duties such as cleaning toilets but is treated with respect and spends most of her time reading and making friends. She takes walks, goes to the gym and watches TV. She has one roommate and is working on innovative ways to do microwave cooking to share with inmates. Her only real complaint is the "terrible" food.    Martha Stewart reported to the Alderson Federal Prison Camp, known as Camp Cupcake, in West Virginia on October 8 to begin serving a five-month sentence. She began her sentence despite her pending appeal in order to sooner put her nightmare ordeal behind her and reclaim her good life. Stewart arrived in good spirits and adjusted well. Prison officials and fellow inmates have been nice. She keeps busy performing chores, taking walks, exercising in the gym, reading, writing, watching television news, and creating innovative microwave recipes. She's received thousands of letters from fans and has had visitors, including her daughter.    Martha Stewart, founder of a multimillion-dollar publishing and home-decorating empire, will be serving a 5-month sentence for lying to federal investigators about her suspiciously timed stock sale. In a web site letter, Stewart says she is adjusting to life behind bars. Stewart is spending time figuring out innovative way to do microwave cooking among other activities. She was touched by the outpouring of support she received from millions of people who visited her web site and urged fans to send donations to the American Cancer Society. Stewart's lawyer has filed an appeal.    Martha Stewart arrived in good spirits for her five-month term at Alderson Federal Prison Camp. She was treated with respect and thought inmates and officials were all nice. She was issued clothing but could also wear an inexpensive watch and earrings. She had one roommate in a dormitory-like building. She exercised, took walks, cleaned toilets, read, subscribed to newspapers, watched TV news, made friends, developed innovative microwave cooking ideas for inmates, and wrote. She kept in touch with supporters through her website and was touched by the many letters. She played scrabble with her daughter Alexis during visits.

summary: On Thanksgiving Day Stewart was able to enjoy a visit from her family, a privilege normally limited to weekends. By Christmas she was calling for sentencing reform particularly for drug and first-time offenders. By mid-January Stewart had tried her hand at ceramics and crocheting. As she completed her term in March she was 20 pounds lighter, having taught yoga and foraged for greens on prison grounds as well as abhorring the food. After leaving Alderson at 12:30 a.m. on March 3, 2005, Martha Steward declared the 5-month experience as "life altering and life affirming."    Martha Stewart spent Halloween, Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's in prison. Her job there was cleaning. During her stay, she did ceramics, crocheted, taught yoga, decorated the chapel for a memorial service, became an expert on vending-machine snacks, and foraged the grounds for fresh greens for the prison salads. She was grateful for the support of her friends, family, colleagues, and fans. Stewart became a prison reform advocate through her experience. She emerged from the Alderson prison on March 4 with head held high, 20 pounds lighter and a lot wealthier, since shares in her company nearly tripled in value.    In a Christmas message posted on her personal web site, Martha Stewart called for sentencing reform. She suggested pushing for reforms in federal sentencing guidelines for nonviolent first-time offenders and particularly for drug offenders, who would be better served in rehabilitation than prison. She is scheduled to be released in early March 2004 and then must spend five months under house arrest. Her company announced that Stewart would host a daytime talk show after her sentence. Since her conviction, her company's share price has nearly tripled increasing her personal stake.    At Alderson Martha had time to think, became a more sympathetic character, and got wealthier as her company's share price tripled. Her family visited at Thanksgiving. Martha's prison job was cleaning, sweeping, vacuuming and raking leaves. Via her website Martha received 15,000 fan e-mails, and said she was safe, fit and healthy but found the loss of freedom and privacy difficult. Fellow inmates shielded her from paparazzi. She picked wild greens to augment the bad food, lost 20 pounds, learned to crochet, taught yoga, tried ceramics, decorated the chapel, ordered seeds for her garden at home, and made to-do lists.

summary: Relief for the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami victims continues. More than $10 billion has been pledged by 42 countries and individuals. Debt relief and loans are also being offered. Concerts, telethons, and charity auctions are among the methods being used to solicit donations. President Bush made a personal contribution of $10,000. Bush recruited Former Presidents Clinton and Bush, his father, to lead fundraising efforts in the U.S. President Bush signed a law permitting U.S. taxpayers to deduct contributions to tsunami relief in January 2005 from their 2004 returns. The Canadian government will match all private donations to approved aid agencies.    Financial contributions for Asian Tsunami relief had exceeded $10 billion by Jan. 12, 2005. Governmental contributions passed $8 billion while private gifts exceeded $2 billion. The United Nations announced that it has secured aid commitments worth $717 million. Governmental contributions were led by Japan with $74m. and Germany at $68m. The outstanding organizational contributor was World Vision Australia which had raised $15.3m through a telethon. Individual contributors were led by a Canadian couple Kroum and Eva Pindoff who gave $4.1m through the Canadian Red Cross which will be matched by the Canadian government to total $8.2m.    Governments have pledged over eight billion dollars in aid for countries hit by the Asian tsunami and private contributions have added over two billion dollars. Countries pledging aid include: Japan, Britain, Germany, Norway, European Commission, the US, Canada, Sweden, Denmark, Russia, China, Australia and Finland. Money raised from ticket sales for a Canadian TV broadcast will go to tsunami relief. An Australian telethon and Melbourne cricket match raised money for relief. Two Chinese banks have made large contributions. Individuals making large contributions include actress Sandra Bullock, President George Bush, a Chinese couple and Kroum and Eva Pindoff, a Canadian couple.    As of 12 January, donations and pledges continued to pour in for tsunami relief. Government donations from 42 countries exceeded $8 billion. Australia had raised more per capita than any other country, including donations made through a telethon and a pop concert telecast simultaneously on all three TV networks. The UN had aid commitments for $717 million for emergency relief, with Japan as the major contributor at $250 million. Private donations reached more than $2 billion, the largest from a Canadian couple, who gave $4.1 million, which the Canadian government will match.

summary: Countries and individuals continue to donate money and other resources to the Indian Ocean tsunami victims. The tsunami killed more than 163,000 people in 11 countries with thousands still missing. Former President Clinton was named the U.N. special envoy for tsunami relief. The Asian Development Bank pledged $800 million additional funds for Indonesia for medium-term economic needs beyond tsunami relief. Saudi Arabia offered the use of five aircraft for relief operations. To reach isolated regions, Switzerland loaned the U.N. three army helicopters which transported refugees and emergency workers as well as tons of humanitarian aid resources.    Tsunami relief efforts continue. China's Shanxi Province provided medical equipment and cash worth $180,000. Saudi Arabia offered the use of five aircraft and a pledge of $100 million. Switzerland lent three army helicopters for use. The government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region granted $192,000 while the Hong Kong Disaster Relief Fund Advisory Committee approved grants from five relief agencies for $2.88 million. Australian tennis ace Lleyton Hewitt raised $31,500 auctioning off tennis rackets while Hong Kong superstar Andy Lou did likewise with stage costume for $38,000.    Countries, organizations and individuals continue to donate money, supplies and equipment to the area devastated by the tsunami. The Tiger Woods foundation is giving $100,000. Memorabilia donated by professional athletes and celebrities has been auctioned for relief funds. China's Shanxi Province sent medical equipment worth $180,000 to Thailand for tsunami relief. The Asian Development bank pledged $800M for Indonesia. Saudi Arabia is offering five of its aircraft and $100M in aid. The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government granted $192,000 for relief work in India, Sri Lanka and Indonesia. Former presidents Bush and Clinton led private US fundraising efforts.    Tsunami relief contributions continued to grow. The UN made Bill Clinton special ambassador for tsunami relief. China's Shanxi Province gave Thailand $180,000 in medical equipment and cash. The Asian Development Bank pledged an additional $800 million to Indonesia. Hong Kong donated $192,000. Saudi Arabia sent five aircraft and $100 million. Switzerland loaned three helicopters to the UN. Tiger Woods gave $100,00, matched by the PGA. Australian tennis player Lleyton Hewitt gave $45,000 from auctions of three of his rackets. Hong Kong stars auctioned off clothes and personal items, with the proceeds going to tsunami relief.

summary: Police arrested Dennis Rader on Feb. 25, 2005 and identified him as the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974-91. BTK had taunted police with letters to them and the media, but efforts to find him failed and in 1979 the letters ceased. They resumed in March 2004 and the investigation of the BTK case reopened. Forensic experts studied DNA swabs that Kansas Governor Sibelius says linked Rader (BTK) to his victims. Little else has been revealed as to how the perpetrator of these crimes was identified and tracked down.    After two false arrests, suspected Wichita, Kansas "BTK serial killer", Dennis Rader, was arrested February 25, 2005. He was held for 10 first-degree murders, from 1974 to 1991, but won't get Kansas's death penalty instituted in 1994. Local and county police, the Kansas Bureau of Investigation, and the FBI worked 31 years on 5,000 tips and evidence provided by BTK: eight letters to police and media, a victim's necklace BTK gave to his girl friend, a victim's driver's license, BTK's recorded voice and crime scene semen, thousands of DNA swabs, BTK's DNA linking to Rader, and facts matching Rader's biography.    Wichita police arrested the BTK strangler during a traffic stop on February 25. Dennis Rader, serial killer of at least 10, sent numerous taunting messages and clues in the 1970's before going silent in 1979. In March 2004, he mailed evidence of a previously unattributed 1986 murder to the Wichita Eagle. More letters, clues and evidence followed. Thousands of tips poured in and police received help from forensics experts. Police long believed BTK graduated from Wichita State University, as Rader had. DNA evidence helped solve the case. Police learned of the last two BTK victims upon his arrest.    Wichita police announced the identification and arrest of serial killer BTK (Bind, Torture, Kill). He is Dennis Rader, a 59-year old church leader and government inspector who police believe murdered ten people between 1974 and 1991 and taunted authorities for their inability to catch him. Police received more than 5,000 tips when BTK resurfaced in 2004 after two decades of silence. The Kansas Bureau of Investigation conducted hundreds of DNA swabs in connection with the investigation. Law enforcement officials revealed nothing about the evidence they have against Rader. According to Governor Sebelius DNA evidence linked him to crime scenes.

summary: Rader confessed to six killings on the day of his arrest, but police revealed little detail. There was much public speculation and some media reports of possible links between Rader and BTK including talk of a computer disc and DNA evidence, but investigators remained tight-lipped. On March 1 Rader was charged with 10 murders with bail set at $10 million. On April 19 Rader waived his right to a preliminary hearing at which the prosecution would explain how the police had tied Rader to the killings. This, as the DA said, "prolongs the agony of the public to know."    Rader's daughter did not turn her father in to police. Wichita investigators continue examining other killings, for possible linkage to BTK. Reportedly, DNA from Rader's daughter facilitated his identification. A computer disk in Rader's final mailing linked to his church. On March 31 Rader was charged with 10 first-degree murders. Bail was $10 million. His next court appearance was March 15. Rader waived his April 19 preliminary hearing. He would plead not guilty at arraignment May 3, and not plead insanity or plea bargain. Rader is no longer secluded from other prisoners. Kansas expected to pay $405,000 for Rader's defense.    Evidence identifying Dennis Rader as the BTK killer was found on a computer disk he mailed to a television station on February 16. Experts linked the disk to a computer at Christ Lutheran Church, where he served as the church council's president. Rader broke his 25-year silence after the Wichita Eagle published an article marking the 30th anniversary of the first BTK killings. Prosecutors cannot yet present their evidence against Rader because he waived his right to a preliminary hearing. Nearby law enforcement agencies are reinvestigating cold cases that bear similarities to the BTK slayings.    Investigators continue to examine unsolved killings over the last 31 years to determine if any can be linked to BTK. Prosecutors cannot seek the death penalty for Rader since the killings occurred before its enactment. For three decades, BTK had toyed with Wichita in letters, poems and packages. It was his most recent mailing to a TV station that helped crack the case: a computer disk traced to the computer at Rader's church. The disk along with DNA evidence led to Rader. Rader waived his right to a preliminary hearing and is expected to plead not guilty.

summary: The FARC, Colombia's largest leftist guerrilla force, commits selective murders, slaughters and other terrorist acts. In 2003, FARC commandos attacked two Bogota pubs, targeting US citizens who frequented them. FARC kidnaps hundreds of people a year for ransom and holds dozens as exchangeables, including Colombian politicians, police officers, soldiers and currently three US citizens. Colombia's government is willing to negotiate a prisoner swap with FARC to free rebel hostages, including the three Americans. The move is encouraged by the UN. So far FARC has not agreed to the government's terms. FARC has ordered its troops to kill Colombia's president.    The Columbian Navy captured a member of the rebel group, Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (FARC), who was believed to be involved in slaughtering five members of the same family. US warned US citizens in Columbia of a possible spike in "terrorist activity." FARC, with about 17,000 fighters and a smaller leftist guerilla group are locked in a 40-year civil war with the government. FARC allegedly finances itself through drug trafficking and kidnappings. About 3,500 people are killed yearly. Columbia's president is ready to negotiate a prisoner swap with FARC.      The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (FARC), the largest and oldest guerilla organization in Columbia, allegedly finances itself through drug trafficking and kidnappings. FARC, which may have 20,000 combatants, is accused of committing murders and slaughters as well as terrorist acts in different part of Columbia. FARC kidnaps hundreds each year for ransom and holds dozens of "exchangeables" including politicians, police, soldiers, and three US contractors. Columbia's President Alvaro Uribe has appealed for international support in his country's war against the rebel groups. Uribe has indicated a readiness to negotiate a prisoner swap with FARC.    Colombian President Pastrana held talks with FARC and designated a safe haven until FARC hijacked an airliner and kidnapped a senator. In 2003 FARC bombed American-frequented pubs and abducted three Americans after a plane crash. In 2004 FARC killed five members of a Colombian family and bombed a peasant home, killing one. The US designated FARC a terrorist organization and aided Colombia financially in its anti-FARC war. President Uribe offered to swap 50 jailed rebels for 50 hostages. FARC-government fighting kills 3,500 yearly. A FARC bomb narrowly missed Uribe in 2002. Uribe is pursuing an aggressive military offensive against FARC.

summary: In November, Colombian police arrested a FARC assassin, the army killed a FARC leader, and the court approved the extradition of a FARC chief to the US to face narcotics trafficking and money laundering charges. FARC rebels murdered four indigenous Indian leaders in less than a week. The government and FARC continued to argue over details of a prisoner swap. The UN urged Colombia to speed up negotiations for hostage release. December 2, the government announced it would pardon 23 FARC members to facilitate reaching a humanitarian accord with FARC. Colombian police may have kidnapped a FARC rebel in Venezuela.     FARC rejected a government proposal to hold talks aimed at exchanging rebels for hostages held by the guerillas. FARC asked the president to grant them the two southern demilitarized zones, before discussions could take place. The government denied their request because it has to guarantee the safety of the people across the country. The United Nations urged hostage release. The rebel groups released 12 hostages. The Columbian government plans to pardon more than 30 members of FARC as they negotiate a prisoner swap.    FARC rejected the government proposal for talks aimed at exchanging jailed rebels for hostages unless two southern counties were demilitarized. The government rejected that demand but released 50 jailed guerillas to build confidence. FARC followed with release of five kidnap victims. FARC killed another indigenous leader, Pervis Pacheco of the Kankuamo Indians and are believed to have killed the leader of Arhuaco Indians. Columbia's Supreme Court approved extradition of a FARC chief, among others, to the US to face charges of narco-trafficking and money laundering. The government was to pardon 23 FARC members as the two sides negotiate prisoner exchanges.    The Colombian government again refused FARC's request for two southern demilitarized zones before prisoner exchange discussions. FARC holds 1600 hostages. Police arrested a top FARC assassin responsible for over 50 assassinations, including a mayor and town councilor, and ordering hostages killed when families failed to pay ransoms. FARC killed four indigenous leaders of the Kankuamo, Yanacona and Arhuaca Indians. The government released 50 jailed guerrillas and pardoned 23. Five FARC rebels died in a clash with the army. Colombia approved extradition of a FARC chief to the US. A FARC leader was seized in Venezuela and moved to Colombia.

summary: On June 16, 2005 Rep. Randall "Duke" Cunningham insisted there was nothing wrong with his living on a yacht owned by the executive of MZM, Inc. for which he had helped gain government contracts or selling a San Diego home for $1,675,000 to the executive who resold it for $975,000. On July 1 federal agents raided Cunningham's San Diego residence and the MZM offices and yacht in Washington. Cunningham soon announced that he would not seek reelection and the executive stepped down. On August 13 Cunningham asked donors for permission to use their campaign contributions for legal expenses.    By July 2005 U.S. Representative Randall Cunningham was under investigation by the FBI, U.S. Attorney's Office, Defense Criminal Investigative Service, the IRS and a federal grand jury probe. He received defense contractor MZM Inc's PAC money and personal donations from MZM President, Mitchell Wade. Wade paid a supposedly inflated price for Cunningham's and Cunningham paid Wade questionably little money to live on Wade's yacht in DC. Cunningham promoted MZM defense contracts, contributed to and served on a Wade-run charity board, and spoke at an MZM company party. Cunningham requested donors' permission to transfer campaign funds to his legal defense fund.    The FBI and other federal agencies are investigating Rep. Randall "Duke" Cunningham for selling his house in November 2003 to a military contractor, Mitchell Wade, for an inflated price. Agencies are probing Wade's efforts to repay Cunningham for his support in gaining federal contracts. Cunningham was living on Wade's yacht, which has also raised questions about improper financial links. He defended his boat arrangement as proper saying that he paid fees and services in lieu of rent. Cunningham is asking his contributors, including Wade, for permission to use their campaign donations for his legal defense.    Randall "Duke" Cunningham, R-California, is a favorite of defense contractors who contribute heavily to his political campaign. The CEO of one company, MZM, Mitchell Wade, contributes to Cunningham's campaign and PAC, but  supports the congressman in other ways. When in Washington, Cunningham lives aboard Wade's yacht docked at a Potomac River yacht club and pays only docking fees. Wade purchased Cunningham's home in San Diego for over  $1.6M and a few months later sold it for a $700,000 loss suggesting that Cunningham was paid an inflated price. After that sale, Cunningham bought another home for over $2.5M.

summary: Cunningham resigned from Congress on Nov. 28, 2005 after pleading guilty to taking at least $2.4 million in bribes to help four unnamed co-conspirators win defense contracts. The FBI continued its investigation of defense contractors. On Feb. 18 prosecutors recommended that Cunningham serve the maximum ten years in prison, pay $1.5 million in taxes and forfeit $1.85 million in bribe money and items provided by co-conspirators. On March 5 he was sentenced to 8 years and 4 months in prison and ordered to pay $1.8 million in restitution.    On November 28, 2005 Cunningham pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit at least $2.4 million in bribes, the most ever congressional bribes, and $1 million tax evasion. Wade was indicted. Three unindicted co-conspirators were Brent Wilkes, ADCS, Inc.; Thomas Kontogiannis; and John T. Kongogiannis. Prosecutors could have asked for 20 years incarceration, but requested 10 years, payment of $1.5 million in taxes and penalties, and forfeiture of $1.85 million in bribes. Wade pled guilty February 24, awaiting sentencing. On March 3, Cunningham was sentenced to eight years and four months, the longest for any congressman, and $1.8 Million restitution.    Rep. Randy Cunningham resigned from Congress after pleading guilty to taking at least $2.4 million in bribes to help friends and contributors win federal defense contracts. The FBI is still conducting its investigation of defense contractors and others tied to Cunningham. He kept a "bribe menu" on congressional stationary indicating how much he demanded in exchange for federal contracts. A federal judge sentenced Cunningham to eight years and four months in prison. Cunningham was also ordered to pay $1.8 million in restitution.    Duke Cunningham resigned from Congress after pleading guilty to taking $2.4M in bribes from defense contractors. Cunningham pled guilty to one count of tax evasion and one count of conspiracy to commit bribery, tax evasion, wire and mail fraud. Cunningham had received cash, cars, rugs, antiques, furniture, yacht club fees, moving expenses and vacations for helping contractors win government contracts. A federal judge sentenced Cunningham to eight years and four months in prison. The government seized Cunningham's share of profits from the $2.6M sale of his home. The IRS will auction the gift items that Cunningham illegally received.
