summary: The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) and the French National Space Center have signed an agreement to initiate a satellite project which will gather atmospheric data. India will build the satellite and France the scientific instruments. ISRO is also considering scientific experiments from the US, UK, Sweden, Bulgaria and Germany for an unmanned lunar mission. India hopes to launch a manned mission within seven years. ISRO is assisting the Jharkhand Space Application Center launch a telemedicine satellite system to connect doctors with rural communities. Afghanistan is requesting to piggyback on the telemedicine system to assist their citizens.    The space agencies of India and France have signed an agreement to cooperate in launching a satellite that will help make climate predictions more accurate. The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) has short-listed experiments from the US, UK, Sweden. Bulgaria and Germany for a slot on its unmanned moon mission, Chandrayaan-1. The European Space Agency and NASA will have x-ray and laser equipment on the satellite. The ISRO will provide satellite connectivity to the Jharkhand Space Application Center for a telemedicine system to connect villagers with doctors at renowned hospitals. This network will also function in Afghanistan.    The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) and France will cooperate on a satellite to track tropical atmospheric conditions. ISRO has short-listed experiments from five nations (US, UK, Sweden, Bulgaria, Germany) for a slot on India's unmanned moon mission, Chandrayaan-1, which is to map the lunar surface. India can send a man into space within seven years. Its first astronaut flew on the Soviet Salyut 7 in 1984. Another died in the Columbia shuttle disaster. India plans a telemedicine system to connect hospitals and patients via satellite. India plans flight-testing of its cryogenic rocket. It sought black-market electrical components for rockets.    India's space program is developing on several fronts. India is planning an unmanned moon mission to map the moon's surface and produce a chemical map of the moon. Experiments from five countries (the U.S. and four European nations) are short-listed for this satellite. It has an agreement with France to launch a satelite perhaps in 2008 to make climate predictions more accurate. It will set up a telemedicine system, linking doctors at the best hospitals with patients across India. Afghanistan has asked India for help setting up a similar program in Afghanistan using Indian satellites.

summary: India successfully launched two satellites from one rocket for the first time. To decrease costs and increase launches, India developed a universal launch pad for all future vehicles. India will host two international space conferences (planetary exploration and space law). India has signed an agreement with the European Space Agency and is talking with NASA regarding their participation in India's unmanned lunar launch. India's launch of the INSAT-4A has been delayed by the European Space Agency. Boeing cancelled their agreement with India to jointly produce communication satellites. India and Russia are collaborating on the development of a youth communication satellite.    For the first time, India is set to launch two satellites in a single mission. One is for mapping and the other for communications. India will host twin international conferences on planetary exploration and space law. Some 225 delegates including many from the US, China, Japan, Canada, France, Malaysia, Sri Lanka and Indonesia will attend. The ISRO announced the payloads from the US, Bulgaria, Germany and Britain for the Chandrayaan-1 mission. Launch of the Indian INSAT-4A communications satellite from French Guyana has been delayed. India and Russia are working on a satellite for communication between youths of the two countries.    India's space program began in 1972. It aspires to be a major space power. India developed a unique universal launching pad and plans a sophisticated propellant plant for its launch vehicle, delayed by sanctions following India's 1998 nuclear testing. India has launched eleven remote-sensing satellites and two satellites in one mission. Communication satellites include Hamsat for Ham radio and distance-learning Edusat. India and Russia plan a youth communication satellite. In 2005 ISRO hosted international conferences on planetary exploration and space law. Europe's Ariane program problems delayed launch of India's telecast and communication satellite INSAT-4A. Boeing withdrew from Indian satellite cooperation.     The Indian Prime Minister has criticized economic sanctions imposed after the 1998 nuclear weapons tests, but noted that these have not hindered India's scientific progress. India launched one rocket carrying two satellites, one for more detailed mapping, the other for home radio operators. Its first unmanned moon mission, scheduled for 2007-2008, will carry three European payloads and perhaps one U.S. payload. Meanwhile India is working with Russia to develop a satellite to enable youths in the two countries to communicate. It will host twin international conferences on planetary exploration and space law for about 225 delegates in June.

summary: In October, 2004, the Dover, PA School Board ordered that biology students be told evolution "is a theory, not a fact" and "intelligent design is an explanation of the origin of life that differs" from evolution, and encouraged to read "Of Pandas & People", added to the school library. Trial began September, 26, 2005. Plaintiffs argued intelligent design is not scientific, but religious; that board members had religious motivation; and that intelligent design and "Pandas" are recast creationism which has been banned from public school science classes by the Supreme Court as a violation of the first amendment's establishment clause.    The Dover, Pennsylvania school board passed a resolution in October 2004 requiring 9th grade biology students be told that evolution is a theory, not a fact, and that intelligent design is an alternative explanation of the origin of life. The board is being sued by 11 parents of students who charge it is trying to promote a religion in violation of the US Constitution. The school board argues it is informing students about differences of opinion, not endorsing any religious view. The trial is underway.    Pennsylvania's Dover School Board voted requiring teachers to read a brief statement about intelligent design to students before teaching classes on evolution. Intelligent design implies that nature is so complex it must be the work of a single creator rather than evolution. The school board stated that intelligent design provides an alternative to teaching evolution and denies that it is "religion in disguise." Dover parents brought suit against the school board charging that teaching "intelligent design" is a clear violation of the principle of separation of church and state.    The Dover, Pennsylvania, school board passed a resolution requiring students in a 9th grade biology course be told evolution "is a theory, not a fact" and "intelligent design is an explanation of the origin of life that differs" from evolution. Board members who voted 6-3 for the measure made it clear they believed the origin of life was guided by a heavenly hand. Eleven Dover families are suing the school district alleging the policy violates the constitutional separation of church and state. The American Civil Liberties Union and Americans United for Separation of Church and State are assisting the parents.

summary: Defendants argued intelligent design is science, not religion, because its testable "irreducible complexity" claim implies an intelligent designer but not necessarily God. One board member lied to hide that a church bought the "Pandas" books. On December 20, 2005 the judge ruled that the board's action violates the constitution. "Intelligent design is "a religious view, a mere re-labeling of creationism". He excoriated board members for lying in their testimony, for not bothering to understand intelligent design and for the "breathtaking inanity of the Board's decision". The ruling is binding only in one Pennsylvania district. Dover will pay large legal fees.    For three weeks plaintiffs in the Kitzmiller vs. Dover Area School District trial presented expert witnesses who testified that intelligent design does not meet the definition of science because it cannot be proved or disproved. For the next three weeks, the defense called witnesses who testified that intelligent design is not based on religious beliefs, but on observable, physical evidence from nature. The judge ruled that compelling teachers to present intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the Constitution. Dover residents ousted all eight school board members running for re-election who put their town in the global spotlight.    At the trial, a biochemistry professor at Lehigh and lawyers at the Thomas More Law Center testified for teaching intelligent design as a credible scientific theory. Scientists testifying for the parents dismissed intelligent design because it can't be tested by experiment. A federal judge ruled that teaching intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the constitution. He wrote that the overwhelming evidence established that intelligent design is a religious view and not a scientific theory and its inclusion in public schools violates the separation of church and state.    Both sides agreed to a bench trial without a jury, common in First Amendment cases where arguments are about legal rather than factual issues. At the trial, board members said they wanted to "encourage critical thinking." However, the parents presented evidence the board's purpose was religious and the intelligent design statement was a compromise after they could not teach creationism. The trial judge ruled that compelling biology teachers to present intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the constitution. Four days after final arguments in the case, Dover residents ousted all eight school board members running for re-election.

summary: Steroid use appears rampant in Major League Baseball based on former player revelations and the BALCO steroid distribution scandal. Steroids were banned by the League in 2004 but it did not include designer or precursor steroids. The new Anabolic Steroid Control Act makes steroid precursors controlled substances. Congressional hearings on steroid use are being held. Former and current team members and League officials are being called to testify, some by subpoena. The League's testing program is weak compared to World Anti-Doping Agency standards. Lawmakers are considering stronger action if the League does not impose mandatory bans to police the League.    Major League Baseball players who have admitted to using steroids include Ken Caminiti, Mark McGwire and Jose Conseco. Players suspected of steroid use include Barry Bonds, Sammy Sosa, Jason Giambi, Rafael Palmeiro, Ivan Rodriguez and Juan Gonzalez. MLB's recently toughened penalties of fines from $10,000 to $100,000 and suspensions from 10 days to one year are far below international anti-doping standards. US lawmakers passed the Anabolic Steroid Control Act which added steroid precursors to the list of controlled substances. In their investigation of steroid use in Major League Baseball, lawmakers found the penalties for positive steroid tests inadequate.    After the death of former baseball star Ken Caminiti, an admitted steroid user, the US House of Representatives amended the Controlled Substances Act to include additional types of steroids. Major league baseball players who are accused of, or admitted, using steroids are Mark McGuire, Jose Canseco, Barry Bonds Sammy Sosa, Jason Giambi and Raphael Palmiero. Commissioner Bud Selig said that the testing program in place for two years showed a drop in positive tests for steroids. That program has been criticized as too lenient. Baseball executives and players union leaders have agreed to toughen penalties for the current season.    Major League Baseball players Ken Caminiti, Mark McGwire, and Jose Canseco admitted taking steroids. Barry Bonds, Sammy Sosa, Jason Giambi, Rafael Palmeiro, Ivan Rodriguez, and Juan Gonzalez are accused or suspected of steroid use. Caminiti claimed half the players used them. 5-7 percent of players tested positive in 2003 and 1-2 percent in 2005. Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig investigated steroid use in 1998 and urged banning over-the-counter sales. A pamphlet in English and Spanish on steroids' effects was distributed to players. Drug tests for players began in 2004. Some steroids became controlled substances. Congress held hearings on baseball steroid use.

summary: Congressional hearings and an undercover probe investigating illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball and other sports continues. Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig admitted the League's policy is not strong enough and has proposed much stricter penalties. They include a 50-game suspension for the first offense and a lifetime ban for the third one. These penalties would apply to minor-league players next year. Selig also requested amphetamines be added to the banned substances. Congress has threatened to implement a testing system unless the League strengthened its policy. The Players Association has not responded to the proposed penalties.    Under pressure from Congress, Major League Baseball's players association toughened drug testing rules and penalties again for the 2006 season. Suspensions will be increased to 50 games for a first offense, 100 for a second, and a lifetime ban for the third. Congress launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball. News of the probe surprised MLB officials. Rafael Palmeiro was suspended 10 days for a positive steroid test. He denied intentionally taking the drug. Other players with 10-day steroid test suspensions were Felix Heredia and Carlos Almanzar. New doping allegations surfaced about Barry Bonds.    Congress has launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in major league baseball. To highlight the problem, baseball heavy hitters Mark McGuire, Raphael Palmeiro and Sammy Sosa testified before the responsible congressional committee. In a letter to the players' union, Selig proposes a 50-game suspension for first offenders instead of the current 10-game suspension. A second offense would result in a 100-day suspension and a third, a lifetime ban. The players' union has concerns since several steroid agents stay in the blood stream for a long period. A one-time user who swore off could show positive in future testing.     Congressional investigators chided Major League Baseball leaders for being uncooperative regarding steroid use and urged star players to take public responsibility for their actions. Congress also launched an undercover probe. Players proposed strengthening the collective bargaining steroid proposal. Bud Selig proposed a 50-game suspension for first offenders, 100-game suspension for second, and lifetime ban for third. 2003 tests showed 104 steroid users. Eleven players were suspended for steroids in 2005. Felix Heredia, Carlos Almanzar and Rafael Palmeiro tested positive. BALCO's Victor Conte and James Valente, Bonds trainer Greg Anderson, and chemist Patrick Arnold were charged or sentenced concerning steroid distribution.

summary: Bamboo shoots must be properly prepared to avoid consuming naturally produced hydrogen cyanide. Bamboo can help makeshift buildings better withstand earthquakes. Innovative bamboo products include: hardwood flooring, paneling, cabinets, countertops, utensils, plates, bowls, cutting boards, shower curtains, and products based on fiber, fiber pulps or veneers. Bamboo's has greater tensile strength than steel. It can be harvested every 3 to 5 years, but entire bamboo stands die-off every 60 years, threatening crop collapse and endangering China's endangered Giant Pandas, who are dependent on arrow bamboo.    Bamboo has many uses. In the home, it is used for flooring, kitchen cabinets, counter tops, and chairs. India is allowing its islands that were struck by the tsunami, to build makeshift houses from bamboo and other woods, which can withstand quakes. Ethiopia hopes to optimize ways of producing bamboo to reduce poverty. Large areas of arrow bamboo provide food for giant pandas in northwest China. Now they are suffering from hunger because large tracts of arrow bamboo died. It takes 10-15 years for new plants to grow.     Bamboo is increasing used for household items and furniture. Its main use remains as a sturdy alternative for hardwood flooring. It has greater tensile strength than steel and costs less and lasts longer than oak flooring. It is environmentally friendly and sustainable since it grows fast and can be harvested within five years. Bamboo shoots are a traditional part of Asian cuisine but must be properly prepared to avoid causing harm. The bamboo plant is the staple panda food. But when the plant flowers and produces seeds, pandas will not eat it and are in danger of starving.    Bamboo is used for flooring, paneling, and furnishings. Its tensile strength is greater than steel, it's harvestable in 3-5 years, and it's inexpensive. India makes bamboo housing for earthquake survivors. Ethiopia is developing its extensive bamboo commercially with China's help. A pulp mill for bamboo-like Arundo donax would benefit Alabama economically but residents fear the plant's invasiveness. California imported it for windbreaks. Giant pandas are increasing in China due to expanded bamboo forests and moving pandas when local bamboo flowers and becomes inedible. KFC in China substitutes bamboo shoots for coleslaw. Incorrect preparation of fresh shoots risks hydrogen cyanide exposure.

summary: China's National Special Program for Food Security assists Nigeria eliminate poverty through Bamboo-based development, using Nigeria's existing under utilized bamboo forests to turn out about 300 byproducts. Over 20 insects plague northwest China's arrow bamboo, a major food source for giant Pandas. The U.S. National Zoo's research advances in giant panda reproductive cycles and artificial insemination will increase endangered giant panda populations in captivity and in the wild. India is building two commercially viable, environmentally friendly, one-megawatt, "green power" bamboo gasification-based electricity plants. A wide variety of bamboo fiber rugs are available, including kiln-dried and carbonized bamboo with polyurethane coatings.    Nigeria is using bamboo to revitalize its agriculture. It has set up a database exploring its abundant bamboo resource to produce byproducts. A state in northeast India plans to set up power stations that run on bamboo to help meet the regions energy needs. A Chinese company has successfully produced fiber from maize and blended it with bamboo fiber to make environment-friendly clothes. Forestry experts in northwest China have identified more than 20 insects, which are causing arrow bamboo to wither and die causing shortages of food for pandas. Help for pandas is being arranged.    China earned as much as $3.5B in foreign exchange from the bamboo-based sector in 2003. Nigeria hopes to follow that example and effectively explore its abundant bamboo resources that can turn out about 300 byproducts. India, second to China in bamboo production, is set to pioneer environmentally friendly power stations that run on bamboo. New products from bamboo include non-slip rugs, fiber for clothing and pre-fabricated quake-shelters. Bamboo's 60-year blooming and seeding cycle and the identification of more than 20 insects that plague arrow bamboo threaten the staple of the pandas' diet.     Retailers offer bamboo-extract towels and bamboo rugs. A Chinese company introduced bamboo fiber in 2004. A bamboo-maize blend makes soft, comfortable, wrinkle-resistant clothing. Bamboo earned China $3.5 billion in 2003. Nigeria is partnering with China to develop its vast bamboo reserve. India is pioneering a power station to turn bamboo into gas then electricity and run local paper mills. Arrow bamboo, plagued by over 20 insects, is low in nutrition but giant pandas' main food. Logging and development threaten bamboo forests. Starving people in Malawi resorted to eating bamboo seeds. Bamboo shoots contaminated with botulism sickened 163 in Thailand.

summary: Barack Obama, a black state senator in Illinois, first came to national attention with his electrifying keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention in July 2004. He went on to win overwhelmingly in the race for U.S. Senator. He was outstanding for his inclusive rhetoric, ability to attract support of liberals and white middle-class voters, and his fund raising for his own and other Democratic candidates. While running his own campaign he stumped for other candidates in more than a dozen states. In November 2004 Barack Obama was already being touted as a future presidential candidate.    Barack Obama graduated Harvard Law School as the first black President of the Harvard Law Review. In 2004 three-term Illinois State Senator Barack Obama won the U.S. Senate seat, with support from white liberals, the white middle class and Chicago south side blacks, to become the third black U.S. Senator in 150 years. He raised a $14 million campaign fund, and gave $400,000 to other Democratic candidates. His lauded keynote speech at the 2004 Democratic Convention kindled such star power he was recruited to stump in a dozen states for presidential nominee John Kerry.    Barak Obama, who was a relatively obscure Senate hopeful just a few months ago, soundly defeated his opponent to become the third African-American US Senator in history. The charismatic Obama catapulted to prominence after giving an electrifying keynote speech at the Democratic National Convention in July. In the following weeks, he came to have such star power that he was recruited to stump for Democratic presidential nominee John Kerry and fellow congressional candidates. He draws the support of voters from all racial and economic groups. Obama is widely touted for a future leadership position in his party.    Barack Obama studied at Columbia and Harvard and led the Harvard Law Review. He became a community organizer in Harlem and Chicago, a civil rights lawyer, and three-term state senator. He won a senatorial nomination over six others in March 2004. He rose to national prominence after his keynote address at the Democratic Convention in July. Annie Leibowitz photographed him for Vanity Fair. He raised $14 million for his campaign and donated to other Democrats. In October he won a landslide victory over Alan Keyes with cross-racial support. He was touted as a future party leader or even presidential candidate.

summary: During his first 15 months as a U.S. Senator (Jan 2005-Mar 2006), Obama became better known and more widely admired. His book "Dreams From My Father" became a bestseller. On the senate floor he demonstrated willingness to work on a bipartisan basis on foreign and domestic issues. In party affairs he continued his successes as a fundraiser. One political analyst said, "The party needs him and for all I know, the nation needs him." Some compared him to John F. Kennedy but Doris Kearns Goodwin warned there were also similarities to William J. Bryan.    Barack Obama is the 5th black Senator in U.S. history. In 2005 he received Harvard Law School's highest award, at which he criticized the Katrina debacle. He published a Time magazine article about President Lincoln. He criticized the Bush administration and called for troop withdrawal from Iraq. In 2006 he met with the Foreign Minister in Israel. First term Senator Obama and senior Senator McCain worked on ethics reform, had a public spat, and made nice. As Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee Vice Chairman, he helped raise $6.5 million. He won a Grammy for his audio book "Dreams of My Father".    Barak Obama was received like a rock star and hero at a luncheon where he was bestowed the Harvard Law School Association Award. Obama took a 10-day tour of the Middle East that included visits to Iraq, Kuwait, Jordan, Palestinian territories, and Israel. He met with Israeli Foreign Minister Shalom and conveyed to him the United States' support for Israel as its leader Ariel Sharon lay stricken by a stroke. Obama won a Grammy Award for his readings of his autobiographical book Dreams From My Father, which became a best seller as he became a rising political star.    At a sold-out luncheon for black alumni at Harvard Law School, Obama was introduced as a rock star and hero. He urged the nearly 1,000 attendees to take personal responsibility in combating urban poverty. In 2005 Obama called for troop reduction in Iraq and a timeframe for phased withdrawal. He visited Israel and met with the Prime Minister and mended a rift with John McCain over lobbying reform. He won the Best Spoken Word Grammy for his autobiographical "Dreams From My Father". He became an important fundraiser for fellow democrats and tweaked the press for its fawning coverage of him.

summary: Cell-phone driving laws are having limited success in passage. Federal bills died in committee. Without a national consensus, existing state and local government laws vary widely. Drivers either ignore or are unaware of existing laws. Enforcement is not uniform. Lobbyists oppose legislation and argue driver distraction by various factors is at fault not cell-phone technology. A survey of cell phone records and accidents in Australia conducted by the U.S. based Insurance Institute for Highway Safety concludes that there is little difference between hand-held and hands-free device driver distraction. The survey confirms that cell-phone use while driving increases injuries and deaths.    The District of Columbia, New York and New Jersey passed legislation that bans using hand-held cell phones while driving. More than 400,000 tickets and warnings have been issued since New York first enacted this law. New Mexico and Chicago City only allow hands-free cell phone. Texas is considering cell phone laws. An Insurance Institute of Highway Safety survey said using any cell phones while driving is dangerous. Drivers using cell phones are four times as likely to end up in a crash as drivers who didn't use a cell phone.    Forty-five countries banned hand-held phone use while driving. In the US only New York, New Jersey and the District of Columbia completely ban hand-held phone use. Some states direct hand-held bans to specific groups such as school bus drivers or those on learner's permits. Some municipalities have enacted bans but some have been overturned by states declining to take action against cell phone use. Some jurisdictions permit hands-free cell phone use. Cell phone bills in Texas and California failed to carry. Laws are often ignored and enforcement spotty. However, Washington police average 600 tickets and 250 warnings each month.    The District of Columbia, NY state, New Jersey, Connecticut and Chicago ban the use of hand-held cell phones while driving. Some states or cities ban use with learner's permits, by school bus drivers, by minors for six months after getting their licenses, or require hands-free phones. Every state has considered restrictions but bills seldom pass. Some states, including Florida, prohibit local governments from restricting cell phone use. Hands-free and hand-held cell phones are equally distracting. Laws are often ignored. Enforcement is spotty. Hand-held phone use while driving is banned in 45 countries, including Australia, Germany, France, Britain and Japan.

summary: The State Legislature group concluded that States are focusing cell-phone legislation on younger drivers and school bus drivers. These laws are more likely to pass and maintain their constituents support. The cell-phone industry states that the percentage of accidents caused are very low. Judging cell-phone law results are difficult due to the lack of clear evidence in accidents except from witnesses or driver admissions. Driver education is a large part of cell-phone law enforcement. A National Highway Traffic Safety Administration survey prompted the Department of Defense to restrict driver cell-phone use on military facilities. Enforcement policies vary by military base.      In 2005, 38 states tried to pass legislation restricting cell phones while driving. Bills were passed or are still being considered in 22 states. The National Transportation Safety Board is urging states to restrict young drivers because teens account for a large share of traffic fatalities and cell phone use increases the problem. However, enforcing laws for young drivers is difficult. Both the U.S. Virgin Islands and Lackland Air Force Base have cell phone laws in place.    Every state has considered legislation on cell phones behind the wheel but only a few have banned them unless they are hands-free. Connecticut and Chicago have joined New York, New Jersey and DC in prohibiting use of hand-held phones. Many states have put limits on teens using cell phones while they drive. Enforcement of laws banning cell phone use while driving is a problem. Nearly everyone supports the laws, nearly everyone ignores them. The Defense Department approved restrictions on cell phone use by motorists but left it for the military services and individual bases to decide how to enforce it.    The US Virgin Islands now bans hand-held cell phone use while driving. Eleven states including Colorado, Delaware, Maryland and Tennessee ban cell phone use by young drivers. California prohibits phone use while driving by bus drivers but not others. Under a Pentagon directive, bans on cell phone use while driving are becoming common on military bases. In 2005, 38 states tried to pass restrictive legislation. Effectiveness is difficult to assess because drivers or witnesses must confirm cell phone use coincided with accidents. Enforcement is difficult because officers can't easily ascertain drivers' ages or if they are using hands-free phones.

summary: In August 2003, former Liberian President, Charles Taylor, accepted asylum in Nigeria from 17 counts of war crimes in Sierra Leone. He has been accused of violating the asylum agreement by harboring Al-Qaeda terrorists, interfering with Liberian presidential elections and an assassination attempt on the Guinea President. The U.N.-backed Special Court for Sierra Leone is pressuring the Nigerian to send Taylor home to Liberia. U.N. peacekeepers would transfer him to Sierra Leone for prosecution. Reversing an earlier statement, Liberia's new President states that Taylor should go directly to Sierra Leone from Nigeria since he has not been indicted in Liberia.    Charles Taylor fled Liberia in August 2003 accepting an invitation from Nigeria for exile. He lived in a luxury villa near the town of Calibar near the border with Cameroon. He was accused of continuing to meddle in Liberian politics, of funding and planning the assassination of the President of Guinea and of backing Sierra Leone rebels. He was also said to give support to Al-Qaeda in its efforts to destabilize West Africa. In March 2006, Nigeria offered to return Taylor to Liberia for trial, but Liberia didn't want him so he remained in his luxury villa.    After Taylor fled Liberia, he took comfortable asylum in Nigeria, agreeing not to interfere in Liberia or other countries. Nigeria would return him to Liberia, only if a newly elected Liberia government formally requested it, but not directly to an international war crimes court in Sierra Leone. From Nigeria, Taylor meddled in Liberia's elections and implicated Al-Qaida and blood diamonds in his attempted assassination of Guinea's president, so he could move to Guinea. In March 2006 the new Liberian president requested Taylor be released to Sierra Leone vice Liberia. President Bush and Obasanjo were to discuss Taylor on March 29.    Former Liberian President Charles Taylor fled to Nigeria in August 2003 and is under house arrest at a riverside villa in Calabar. Taylor regularly defies restrictions against travel, political activity or media contact. He is actively trying to destabilize West Africa, spending money he looted from Liberia. Taylor meddles in Liberian affairs, harbors members of Al-Qaeda, and ordered an assassination attempt against Guinea's President Conte. Nigerian President Obasanjo agreed to turn Taylor over to Liberia but is pressured to send him to war crimes court in Sierra Leone where Taylor is under indictment for crimes against humanity while backing rebels.

summary: Charles Taylor disappeared 48 hours after the Nigerian government rescinded his political asylum. Bowing to international pressure the Liberian government was preparing to take Taylor into custody to extradite him to Sierra Leone. United Nations chief Kofi Annan requested West African countries to deny Taylor refuge and arrest him. Taylor was arrested the next day by Nigerian police while attempting to cross the border into Cameroon. Upon his involuntary return to Liberia he was flown by the United Nations peacekeeping force to Sierra Leone and was read the arrest warrant. Taylor will appear before the Special Court on April 3.    On the night of March 27, 2006 Charles Taylor vanished. His spiritual advisor said he was hiding somewhere in West Africa. On March 29 Taylor was arrested while attempting to cross over into Cameroon. He was detained under armed guard and then placed on a presidential jet bound for Liberia. He left Monrovia, Liberia an hour after arrival on a UN helicopter to Freetown, Sierra Leone where he was delivered to the UN-backed Special Court for Sierra Leone. He was due to make his first court appearance on April 3 at 3 p.m.    Taylor vanished the night of March 27, after the Nigerian government said it would end his asylum and allow him to face indictment by an international court in Sierra Leone. On March 29 he was arrested by Nigeria police trying to escape into Cameroon. He was detained under guard, flown to Liberia, arrested by UN peacekeeping forces, and extradited by helicopter to Sierra Leone on March 30. The Special Court in Sierra Leon indicted Taylor on 11 counts of crimes against humanity, making him the first African head of state to face an international war crimes tribunal.    Taylor vanished two days after President Obasanjo said Liberia could take Taylor into custody. Nigerian police arrested Taylor a day after his escape, as he tried to cross into Cameroon with sacksful of dollars and euros. He was detained under armed guard in a military camp before being put in handcuffs on a presidential jet Wednesday bound for Liberia. An hour after arrival he left for Sierra Leone aboard a UN helicopter. He was to make his first court appearance on Monday, April 3, 2006, the first African head of state to face an international war crimes tribunal.

summary: Electric power networks are vulnerable to physical attacks (conventional explosives or nuclear electromagnetic pulse) and computer attacks (external or internal) against the internet-based supervisory control and data acquisition computers and networks that remotely control power generation and transmission. Recognized cyber-security improvements need to be implemented more comprehensively, especially against documented threats from Al-Qaida, and older, less secure equipment replaced. Network stability and capacity, and ensured power locally, can be improved with on-site power generation that can also increase power available to the network, such as from fuels, solar, wind, and fuel cells. Excess power can be stored as hydrogen.    Security experts warned that terrorists could unleash electromagnetic bombs that can be catastrophic. The U.S. is particularly vulnerable because it relies heavily on telecommunications and electronics. Homeland Security is being urged to set up mechanisms to stop attacks and restore power. Electric company officials have been warned that they need to focus more on cyber-security to prevent hackers from attacking U.S. electric power grids. Many nuclear power plants in the U.S. lack sirens warning of a nuclear emergency if electricity also was blacked out.     Many analysts believe the biggest threat to the power grid is from companies using older equipment that is more susceptible to attack and their reluctance to update to new computers. Former counterterrorism chief Richard Clarke opined that a sophisticated hacker could probably get into each of the three US power networks and bring down sections. Computers make the nation's infrastructure more efficient, but they also make it more vulnerable. Improved planning and additional power plants would seem to improve reliability and lessen the chance for a widespread blackout like the one in 2003. Alternative power sources could also benefit.    Electrical grid vulnerability has grown as equipment is controlled through the Internet or phone, older equipment becomes susceptible to attack, and electric companies' cybersecurity remains inadequate. Homeland Security hasn't yet assessed cyberattack threats. An electromagnetic pulse could damage electrical power systems. In 2003, fifty million Americans lost power in a blackout originating in Ohio. New York has improved power grid monitoring and is increasing in-state generation through fuel cells, windmills, and solar panels. Texas protects its grid by remaining independent. Terrorist attacks are being simulated using computer models. The 2005 Energy Bill calls for increased energy production and grid modernization.

summary: Other power grid vulnerabilities include accidental line cuts during maintenance, equipment malfunction or failure, old grid infrastructure and poor grid design causing power loss over wider areas. Improvements in grid architectures will increase network resilience. Deregulation resulted in lower margins for reserve power capacity and transmission capacity, as well as loss of experienced personnel. As companies specialized more in generation or transmission, supervisory data became proprietary and unavailable to regional grid managers. An August 2005 federal law will create a process for mandating reliability rules. Energy conservation and smart appliances that cut back during power grid stresses can avert blackouts.    The blackout in August 2003 that struck the northeastern U.S. and parts of Canada was primarily caused by the deregulation of the utility companies. Experts said that changes in the industry had several adverse effects, including loss of experienced personnel and lawyers and MBAs now heading these competitive companies rather than engineers. Power plant capacity and its state of repair are proprietary now and not available to system operators who manage regional power grids. The energy law provides for mandatory reliability rules, but no power to enforce rules.    The factor widely considered behind the blackout of 2003 is the deregulation of the electric system. Under a regulated system, utilities could add transmission lines to increase reliability and their costs would be reimbursed through the regulatory process. Market participants prefer lower margins to drive up prices. A new energy bill now provides a mechanism for creating mandatory reliability rules. Some firms have identified advances in technology: cheap, powerful chips, more capable software and broadband communications that will impact on the energy business. Power saving devices and developing alternate power sources can contribute to the reliability of the power system.    California imposed rolling power cuts in 2001 to deal with strains on the grid. In 2005 Los Angeles suffered three significant electrical failures, due to mistakes by workers or automatic systems. In 2005 the US and Canada discussed deregulation of the electric system, widely considered to be a cause of the 2003 blackout. Utilities now have little incentive to invest in transmission lines, keep reserve power to minimize shortages, or share information on power plant operating status. Plants operate closer to reliability limits more often. MBAs and lawyers head power companies rather than engineers. Energy company ownership continues to consolidate.

summary: By April 2005 the cause of legalizing gay marriage was making remarkable headway in Europe and Canada, edging slowly ahead in sections of the U.S. and facing aggressive opposition in some other states. Spain, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Iceland and Finland had legalized the practice. In Canada 7 of the 10 provinces and one of three territories accepted gay marriage. In the U. S. eighteen states had passed constitutional amendments prohibiting it while Massachusetts allows and three New England states, New Jersey, California and Hawaii had taken steps toward allowing it.    Spain joined Belgium and the Netherlands as the only European countries to legalize homosexual marriages. In the US, a judge threw out an amendment to the Louisiana Constitution banning gay marriage. Massachusetts legalized gay marriage in May. Arkansas, Georgia, Kentucky, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon and Utah have all passed constitutional bans on gay marriage. A US judge ruled that California state law effectively bans gay marriage as unconstitutional. Over half of Canada's 10 provinces and tree territories allow same-sex marriage.    Homosexual marriages were legalized in Spain including the right to adopt. Some European countries have passed legislation authorizing gay marriages, but not all give gay couples the right to adopt. Poland's senate approved draft bill allowing same-sex partnerships. In Canada, seven provinces authorized gay marriages. In the U.S., gay marriages are banned in 18 states. Massachusetts legalized gay marriages and Vermont's law applies to civil unions. Judges in California and New York ruled state laws banning gay marriages were unconstitutional.    The Netherlands and Belgium allow gay marriage. Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Iceland, Finland and France give gay couples the same legal rights as married heterosexual couples. Spain approved a bill to legalize homosexual marriages. Poland's upper house approved legal partnership rights. Massachusetts allows homosexual marriage. Vermont and Connecticut allow civil unions. Judges in Louisiana and California declared state bans on gay marriage unconstitutional. Eighteen states including Arkansas, Georgia, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, and Utah ban same-sex marriage. Saskatchewan became the seventh Canadian province to allow gay marriage. The Roman Catholic Church opposes gay marriage.

summary: On June 29, 2005 the Canadian House of Commons passed legislation to legalize gay marriage on a national basis. In Britain a Civil Partnership Act took effect on Dec. 5, 2005 granting some legal rights and tax benefits to gay couples. By March 2006 homosexual rights advocates were demonstrating in favor of gay marriage in Taipei, Taiwan. In the U.S. a Maryland judge threw out a law banning gay marriage, lawmakers in New Hampshire defeated a proposed constitutional amendment banning gay marriage, and seven states were prepared to vote on such amendments in November.    Texas legislators will vote on a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage that is not expected to pass. New Hampshire lawmakers defeated a constitutional ban on gay marriage. The issue is under debate in courts in Maryland, California, New Jersey, New York and Washington State. The US government does not recognize same-sex marriage. Massachusetts is the only state to legalize it, although Vermont and Connecticut allow legalized civil unions. Canada passed landmark legislation to legalize gay marriage everywhere in the country. However, gay marriage is not legal in Sweden and Taiwan. Many countries have legalized civil unions, but not gay marriage.    Canada passed legislation authorizing gay marriages and granting same-sex couples legal rights equal to those in traditional unions. In Sweden, civil unions between homosexuals are legal and the government will decide if the law should be changed to include marriage. Under the Civil Partnership Act passed in Britain, homosexual couples will have the same rights as heterosexual couples. Texas legislation to amend the constitution to ban same-sex marriages is being discussed. Homosexual rights activists urged the Taiwan government to grant homosexual couples the right to marry.    Canada and Spain legalized gay marriage and Britain allowed civil partnerships in 2005. Germany and Switzerland allow registered partnerships. Portugal recognizes de facto couples regardless of sex. Croatia gives gay couples rights equal to de facto heterosexual couples. New Zealand gives them rights equal to married couples. South Africa allows gay couple adoptions. Sweden's Lutheran Church approved gay partnership blessing ceremonies. California, New Jersey, Maine and Hawaii recognize limited forms of gay partnership. State bans on gay unions were rejected by a judge in Maryland and blocked by eleven senators in Texas. Idaho passed a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage.

summary: Three pipeline projects underway to transport natural gas from Asia to Europe are raising political and unspecified environmental concerns. A northern pipeline delivers gas to Germany, France and England. A central one connects Turkey to Romania, Bulgaria and Austria. The southern one supplies Greece and Italy from Turkey. The pipeline to Germany circumvents the concept of a common European policy with Russia. Russia has a monopoly agreement on gas exported from Kazakhstan produced in Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. Russia's actions are viewed as applying political pressure on neighboring countries. The pipelines are expected to begin operating between 2007 and 2010.    Gazprom, the state-controlled Russian gas group and the German company BASF plan a Baltic Sea pipeline to transport Russian gas directly to Europe. The pipeline will be launched in 2010, three years from the original estimate. It will make landfall in northern Germany then continue to the Netherlands and across the English Channel. Austria and Bulgaria plan a gas pipeline from Turkey through Romania, Bulgaria and Hungary to Austria. Construction is to begin on a Turkey-Greece pipeline to transport Caspian and Central Asian natural gas to Europe. An underwater pipeline from Greece to Italy is part of the plan.    Russia's Gazprom will control the Northern European Gas Pipeline, bringing Siberian gas directly to Europe. It will bypass Poland, Ukraine and Belarus, who fear being cut off from Russian gas. Gazprom and Germany's BASF will build it. Gerhard Schroeder, criticized for profiting from a project he supported while German chancellor, will chair the board. Gazprom arranged a monopoly on gas from Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan through Kazakhstan. The Austria-Bulgaria "Nabucco" project is a gas pipeline from Turkey to Austria. A Southern Europe Gas Ring from Turkey through Greece and across the Ionian Sea to Italy is to be completed by 2006.    The Northern European Gas Pipeline, which will bring gas from Northern Siberia through Russia and under the Baltic Sea to northern Germany, then to the Netherlands and under the English Channel to Britain. Poland, the Baltic states, Belarus, and Ukraine are critical of the pipeline, because it bypasses current transit routes through those countries. The Southern Europe Gas Ring project is to transport natural gas from the Caspian Sea area and Central Asia through Turkey and Greece then under the Ionian Sea to Italy. Construction of the Turkey-Greece segment is scheduled to start in July 2005.

summary: Russia restored the reduced gas flow through Ukrainian pipelines which had sparked emergencies throughout Europe raising questions about Russia's reliability. The reduction was critically viewed as a foreign policy tool. Ukraine, accused of gas theft, responded that the withdrawal was routine. Russia was charged with acts of terror in pipeline explosions in Georgia. Croatia and Hungary are considering an Adriatic Sea pipeline to decrease reliance on Russia. The European Union imports some gas from Russia but parts of Europe are mainly Russia dependent. A proposed trans-Caspian pipeline linking gas directly to the West bypassing Russia is causing renewed conflicts.    Gazprom intends to remain the leading gas supplier to Europe and to expand its markets. However, Russia's disruption of gas supplies to Europe during freezing weather raised concerns about the company's ability to ensure steady fuel supplies. Pipelines supplying Russian gas go through Ukraine and each country blames the other for the shortage. Croatia and Hungary are weighing construction of a pipeline from the Adriatic Sea to bring Middle Eastern gas to Europe and decrease reliance on Russian gas. Russia has opposed a US-backed pipeline project that would bypass Russia and link Central Asian gas fields directly to the West.    Faced with mounting criticism, Russia restored gas withheld from Ukraine in an alleged pricing dispute but suspected to be Moscow's meddling in Ukraine's internal politics. Steady fuel supplies from Gazprom became questioned. Austria proposed a gas pipeline from Iran to Austria as part of Nabucco. Gas pipeline explosions in January 2006 were blamed on both Moscow and terrorists. Croatia and Hungary are considering a liquified petroleum gas terminal on the Adriatic coast and a pipeline to Europe to decrease reliance on Russian gas. A US-backed trans-Caspian pipeline is proposed that would bring Central Asian gas to Europe and bypass Russia.    Russia cut the flow of natural gas through the Ukrainian pipeline in early January because of a pricing dispute. The resulting European energy crisis made European governments question Russia's reliability and seek alternative sources. Austria is weighing the construction of a pipeline from Iran through Turkey and the Balkans. Croatia and Hungary are considering a pipeline to bring liquid gas from North Africa and the Middle East. The U.S.supports a proposed pipeline under the Caspian Sea to bring gas from Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan through Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Turkey. Pipeline explosions cut Russia's gas supply to Georgia and Armenia.

summary: "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince," number six in the series by British author J.K. Rowling will go on sale in July 2005. The publication date will be simultaneous in several countries. Bloomsbury Publishing's stock surged with the news. More than 5 million pre-orders have been received by booksellers worldwide. 10.8 million copies of the first printing and 635,000 audio book copies will be available in July. Four separate editions are planned for US and UK audiences. In two separate cases, theft and accidental pre-release sales, injunctions forbidding the leaking of details prior to publication were issued.    J.K. Rowling's sixth novel in the Harry Potter series will go on sale on July 16 in Britain, the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and China. The announcement delighted readers, booksellers, and owners of Bloomsbury Publishing stock, whose shares surged 7%. Within 24 hours, the book shot to Number 1 on Amazon's bestseller list. British police arrested two men for the theft of two copies of the book six weeks before its launch. A Canadian bookstore accidentally sold up to 15 copies about a week early, and a court injunction barred anyone from leaking the plot.    Rowling's sixth Harry Potter novel was announced in December 2004, to go on sale July 16th. Bloomsbury stock surged to an all-time high. Advance orders at Amazon and Barnes & Noble each topped one million. Rowling announced one character wouldn't survive. First printing would be 10.8 million. British police recovered stolen copies from two men preparing to sell them six weeks early. Fifteen copies were sold early in Canada. Court injunctions kept anyone from leaking story details. Warehoused books were kept under 24-hour guard. Rowling invited 70 children from English-speaking nations to join her at Edinburgh Castle for the launch.    The sixth novel in J.K.Rowling's Harry Potter series, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince," will go on sale at 12:01 a.m. on July 16. Long before its release, the book was breaking all publication records. The first U.S. printing was to be 10.8 million copies, with 635,000 copies of the audio book. Amazon.com had more than 1.2 million pre-orders world-wide and bookstores expected to sell 50,000 copies an hour for the first 24 hours. In early June, five warehouses were under tight security as they prepared the books for shipment.

summary: A Canadian store that sold copies of the book before the launch begged for their return. An unprecedented court injunction was issued to prevent those purchasers from reading, copying, selling, or talking about the book prior to the launch. In the first 24 hours available, the book sold 6.9 copies in the US. The second printing is being delivered to US bookstores. A Braille edition will be available within 3 days of the initial launch so the sight impaired will not have to wait. The Potter books have been translated into 63 languages with more than 300 million copies sold.    Special events were planned at bookstores worldwide, including Asia, for the much-anticipated release of Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince. The author herself was to host a special celebration at Edinburgh Castle for 70 children from around the world. A US drug store accidentally sold one copy of the book ahead of the release date. The customer agreed to return the book. The book shattered publishing records in the United States. A Braille edition of the latest Harry Potter book is was released on July 19. In October, French, Portuguese and Chinese editions of the book were released.    The publisher offered signed editions and gift packs to customers of a Canadian supermarket and US drug store who accidentally bought books early. A judge ordered Canadians not to read it until release day. A Braille edition came out three days after the simultaneous worldwide launch. French, Portuguese and Chinese translations came out in October. The 70 children attending the Edinburgh Castle launch were to write articles after being granted Rowling's only press conference. The book shattered US records, selling 6.9 million copies in the first day. A second printing hit stores immediately. Pre-orders were double those for book five.    Several copies of the sixth Harry Potter book were sold accidentally before 16 October, one in a New York drug store and 14 in a Canadian grocery store. A Canadian judge ordered those purchasers not to even read the book until the official publication date. The sale of more than 6.9.million copies in the first 24 hours in the U.S. broke all records. A second printing was already on bookshelves. The Braille edition was released three days after publication. The French translation was released on 1 October; the Portuguese, on 14 October; and the Chinese, in mid-October.

summary: President Bush's nomination of Harriet Miers for the Supreme Court caused much consternation. The White House counsel was endorsed by the Democratic Senate leader while the Republican conservative base was splintered. Moderate Republicans sided with their president while most Democrats and liberal advocacy groups stayed out of the fray. On Oct. 12, 2005 Bush tried to promote confirmation by vouching for Miers as an evangelical Christian, but conservatives said the issue was not religion but her lack of qualifications. On Oct. 21 the Senate Judiciary Committee found Miers' answers to a committee questionnaire "inadequate," "insufficient," and "insulting."    President Bush nominated his longtime lawyer and friend Harriet Miers for the U.S. Supreme Court to replace retiring Justice Sandra Day O'Conner. Miers, currently White House counsel, would join Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg as the second woman on the court. Conservatives urged Mr. Bush to withdraw her nomination saying that she lacks the qualifications having never been a judge and has little experience in constitutional law. They further state that her nomination looks like cronyism. There is also concern that her religious belief may influence her decisions as a Justice.     President Bush nominated his longtime lawyer and friend Harriet Miers for the US Supreme Court. The announcement initially drew kind words from some Democrats but skepticism from some conservatives. Some Bush critics charged cronyism in the selection. Miers has few credentials of any kind to carry her into confirmation hearings and little experience in constitutional law. The Judiciary Committee called her response to a questionnaire inadequate, insufficient and insulting. Bush stated that part of Miers life is her religion and that appeared to further inflame the controversy. Conservatives continued to deride Miers' nomination and called for its withdrawal.    President Bush has nominated White House Counsel Harriet Miers to the Supreme Court. The nomination must be confirmed by the U.S. Senate. There is increasingly strong opposition to the nomination, with outrage expressed by conservatives such as Pat Buchanan and Charles Krauthammer. The major objections are that she has few credentials or qualifications and that the nomination looks like cronyism. Bush cited religion as one criterion for her selection. She is scheduled to face the Senate Judiciary Committee in November. The committee sent her a questionaire, but found her responses "inadequate" and "insulting" and asked her to redo it.

summary: On Oct. 27, 2005, a little more than three weeks after offering the nomination of Harriet Miers, President Bush announced that she had withdrawn her nomination. Many expressed sympathy for how she had been treated. Republicans, including Miers herself, blamed failure of the nomination on the Senate Judiciary Committee's demands for documents from the White House, but the committee chair denied intruding on executive privilege. Democrats blamed the failure on right-wing ideologues. Sen. Lott (R-MS) blamed it on a nomination based on cronyism. On Oct. 28 President Bush said he would quickly select another candidate.    Harriet Miers withdrew her nomination from consideration as a Supreme Court justice. Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee questioned her conservative credentials, lack of judicial experience and criticized her for not completely answering a questionnaire about her work at the White House. Others said the White House bungled the nomination from the start. Many agreed that although she is a very capable person, President Bush shouldn't have chosen someone not qualified to serve on the Supreme Court.     President Bush announced that Harriet Miers had withdrawn her nomination for the Supreme Court. The announcement was met with a blend of regret, relief and a feeling that she had been treated poorly. Miers said her withdrawal was to avoid burdening the White House over access to documents on advice she gave Bush since lawmakers had requested those documents. Some senators said that she had been the victim of bad handling and the White House had capitulated to the far right wing of the Republican Party. Right Wing partisans expressed relief and some jubilation at her withdrawal.    Harriet Miers withdrew her nomination to the Supreme Court three and a half weeks after its initial announcement. Bush declared on 27 October that his choice had withdrawn her name and that he had "reluctantly accepted" her decision. She claimed that the fight over her nomination would be a burden for the White House. She also said that she wanted to protect the independence of the executive branch, citing the battle over access to her White House legal writings. She will continue to serve as White House counsel. Bush promised to name a replacement "in a timely manner."

summary: The ivory-billed woodpecker (Campephilus principalis), thought extinct since 1944, was seen again February 11, 2004 near where it was last seen in the "Big Woods" region of eastern Arkansas. Several independent sightings and video by teams from the Cornell University's Laboratory of Ornithology and the Nature Conservancy, ruled out the similar pileated woodpecker and confirmed the rediscovery, which was kept secret for over a year to prepare to protect the bird's habitat not least from a flood of bird watchers, for which private groups, including The Nature Conservancy spent about $10 million, and the Interior Department committed over $10 million.    The ivory-billed woodpecker, a bird long thought extinct, has been sighted in the swamp forests of eastern Arkansas for the first time in more than 60 years. The bird disappeared after large-scale logging felled thousands of acres of forest. In February 2004, a sighting was thought to be the ivory-billed woodpecker. There have been 15 sightings captured on video although researchers can't determine how many were seen. The government proposed $10 million for efforts to protect the bird. Private groups will contribute another $10 million.     The ivory-billed woodpecker, a magnificent bird long thought extinct, has been sighted in the cypress and tupelo swamp of the Cache River National Wildlife Refuge in Arkansas. Bird experts, government agencies and conservationists kept the discovery secret for more than a year while they worked to confirm the discovery and protect the bird's territory. The ivory-billed woodpecker once ranged from Texas to North Carolina but became extinct in the US because its habitats of old growth forest and swamps were destroyed. There have been 15 sightings of the bird since February 2004 during more than 7,000 hours searching.    The ivory-billed woodpecker, thought for 60 years to be extinct, has been discovered in a remote Arkansas swamp. Its existence has been confirmed by at least 8 sightings, a 4-second video, and its distinctive "double-knock" drumming. The first sighting was in February 2004 but was kept secret for over a year while experts confirmed the discovery and protected the bird's territory. Private groups and individuals have raised $10 million for protection of the woodpecker and its environment, while the federal government has proposed $10 million in federal funds. Massive logging had destroyed the woodpecker's habitat.

summary: In July 2005 ornithologists Richard Prum, Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson, submitted a paper questioning the sufficiency of the evidence for the ivory-billed woodpecker's rediscovery. They withdrew their paper after hearing audio recordings of calls and raps reportedly matching 1930's recordings of the bird. But they and others remained skeptical. In December over 100 researchers and volunteers began an intensive six-month search across 500,000 acres of Arkansas wetlands seeking definitive evidence of the bird. A local town benefited from bird watching tourists. In January 2006 Jackson published an article saying claims for proof of the bird's existence constitute "faith-based ornithology".    Biologists question evidence in sightings of rare ivory-billed woodpecker. The issue is whether four seconds of fuzzy videotape is an ivory-billed or pileated woodpecker. Recordings of the ivory-billed woodpecker's distinctive double-rap sounds convinced scientists of this bird's existence. A crew from Cornell Lab and its partner agencies will train 100 volunteers for a six-month search of 500,000 acres in the eastern Arkansas wetlands. An ivory-bill specialist criticized the finding saying the bird's existence hasn't been confirmed and the videotape shows a pileated woodpecker.    Three biologists questioned reported sightings and a fuzzy videotape as sufficient evidence that the ivory-billed woodpecker is not extinct. However, more recent audio recordings of calls and distinctive double-rap sounds removed their doubts. Cornell ornithologists made 17,000 hours of recordings near the Cache and White rivers in Arkansas. The discovery raised concerns that this habitat could be inundated with bird watchers. Cornell will train 100 volunteers for a six-month search for the bird. Federal authorities have provided $10.2M toward the effort and the Nature Conservancy has bought 18,000 acres of Big Woods habitat to set aside for the bird.    The rediscovery of the ivory-billed woodpecker was challenged in late April, almost three months after its announcement. Three biologists planned to publish a paper saying that the evidence was insufficient, a conclusion also reached by Sibley, author of well-known field guides. But two of the scientists were given recordings based on 18,000 hours of audio and, on the basis of this "new evidence," they withdrew their challenge and the paper was not published. In January 2006, however, the third biologist voiced the strongest criticism to date, saying that he was still not convinced. The search continues.

summary: Pope John Paul II, 84, died in Rome on April 2, 2005 from Parkinson's disease. Sunday his body lay in state at the Vatican's Apostolic Palace. St. Peter's Basilica was closed to the public to prepare for the funeral and interment on Friday. Major security measures including a no-fly zone and marksmen are being undertaken to protect the 200 state leaders attending. Condolences and mourners from around the world are arriving in Rome. A tent city has been erected as a camp for mourners. Millions more are mourning worldwide. The College of Cardinals is beginning preparations to select a successor.    Following Pope John Paul II's death on April 2, mourners gathered worldwide. Chinese Catholic Bishops sent condolences to the Vatican. Philippine Catholics express deep grief as church bells tolled. Over 500,000 people signed an online condolence book. On April 3, the late Pope's body lay in state in the Vatican's Apostolic Palace. Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims arrived from Europe and around the world to pay their respects. Some 800,000 gathered in Krakow, Poland for a memorial mass. Hundreds of dignitaries, leaders and heads of state from around the world headed to Rome for the funeral.    Pope Paul II died after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. The Pope's body was displayed at the Vatican's Apostolic Palace and on Vatican television and will be interred in the crypt of Saint Peter's Basilica. A vast security operation went into effect as dignitaries and over a million pilgrims from around the world arrived paying their last respects. Near Krakow, Poland, 800,000 people gathered for a mass in memory of the Polish-born pope. More than half a million people have "signed" a condolence book in cyberspace.    Pope John Paul II died on Saturday night, 2 April, after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. He had had acute breathing problems for two months and had suffered a heart attack two days before his death. His body was displayed at the Vatican's Apostolic Palace on Sunday. The funeral is to be held on Friday. Two hundred world leaders are expected to attend, creating an enormous security problem. Meanwhile more than a million pilgrims have been gathering to pay their respects. His remains are to be interred in the crypt of St. Peter's Basilica.

summary: The funeral service for Pope John Paul II was held Friday, April 8. Mourners interrupted the funeral service by calling for sainthood for Pope John Paul II now. Friday was declared a national day of mourning in Poland, home of his birth, and in Malawi, South Africa. In Krakow live images of the service were telecast from Rome. Monuments will be erected throughout Poland to honor the late Pope. One monument was inaugurated immediately on Saturday in the Rakowicki cemetery, Krakow where members of his family are buried. Cardinals will begin the conclave to elect a successor on April 18.      The world said a final farewell to Pope John Paul II at his solemn funeral on April 8. A huge throng of mourners applauded as his coffin was carried from Saint Peter's Basilica and placed before the altar. Dignitaries stood in respect. The requiem mass followed centuries of solemn ritual. He was interred in the crypt of Saint Peter's Basilica. The late Pope's native Poland declared a national holiday. Hundreds of thousands of mourners gathered to watch the televised funeral. Hundreds gathered for interfaith prayers at a Warsaw synagogue. Cardinals will meet on April 18 to elect a new pontiff.    The funeral ceremony for Pope Paul II began in Saint Peter's Square in front of a huge throng of mourners including state leaders who applauded as the coffin was placed on the altar. In Tokyo, Japan, diplomats and government officials joined 1,500 Catholics in a mass mourning for the pope. Several hundred people of all faiths prayed at a Warsaw synagogue. The Grand Rabbi of Poland led the ecumenical prayer. A monument to Pope Paul II was inaugurated in a Krakow cemetery, where the late pope's family is buried.    An open-air requiem mass was held for Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square from 10am-12:30 pm on Friday. As the mass ended, lengthy applause broke out from the enormous throng of mourners. The body, in a plain cypress wooden coffin, was laid to rest in the crypt of St.Peter's Basilica following the funeral. On Saturday a monument was unveiled at the Krakow cemetary where the pope's family is buried. The cardinals will meet in secret to elect a successor.

summary: Prior to parliamentary elections on Feb. 27, 2005 about 300 opposition activists gathered in Kyrgyzstan's capital Bishkek demonstrating in favor of democratic elections and calling for President Askar Akayev to step down at the end of his second term in October. The administration staged a counter-demonstration. After Akayev won overwhelming election victories the opposition charged the government with mass election violations, blocked roads, occupied government buildings, and held a regional governor and a district chief hostage. Akayev ordered investigation and negotiations and fired the interior minister and prosecutor general while police dispersed crowds in Bishkek.    In February 2005 rallies in Bishkek urged President Akayev to step down as promised and constitutionally required after October presidential elections, fearing a referendum to continue his reign. Akayev supporters won a landslide parliamentary victory. Opposition leaders and the European Organization for Security and Cooperation charged the elections were flawed. By March 16 opposition forces rallied, blocked roads, occupied government buildings, demanded Akayev's resignation, and took hostage a regional governor and district chief. On March 20 four policemen were beaten after police fired shots at demonstrators. Akayev ordered investigations into election fraud charges and fired the interior minister and prosecutor-general.    Kyrgyz oppositionists, fearing President Akayev might hold onto power longer than his constitutional two terms, rallied and urged him to step down. He refused, saying elections were fair, opposition leaders were unnecessarily inciting civil war, and talks were the solution to the crisis. The opposition refused to accept a landslide victory by Akayev supporters in parliamentary elections and claimed fraud. They blocked roads, occupied government buildings, and took a governor and district chief hostage. When police fired shots to dispel rioters, crowds beat four policemen to death. Akayev ordered fraud claims investigated and replaced the interior minister and prosecutor-general.    Parliamentary elections were held in Kyrgyzstan on 27 February, with presidential elections planned for October. Akayev supporters won a landslide victory in most areas, but both opposition leaders and western observers cited mass violations. Run-off parliamentary elections were held in many regions on 13 March. The opposition was defeated but refused to accept the results and demanded Akayev's resignation. Even before the election, opposition leaders had been calling for Akayev to step down as President at the end of October in accordance with the constitution. But Akayev refused to resign or to annul the election results.

summary: On March 24, 2005 mass protests outside the presidential compound in Bishkek turned violent. Demonstrators broke into the building and beat several officials severely. Akayev fled the country for Russia and soon announced in Moscow that he would resign if the Kyrgyzstan government would guarantee his safety. On April 3 a Kyrgyzstan parliamentary delegation arrived in Moscow and after 3 hours of talks Akayev signed a resignation document. He also taped an 18-minute farewell address to be played in Bishkek while he remained in Moscow. New presidential elections are scheduled for June 26.    On March 24, 2005 protestors stormed the main Kyrgystan government building and Akayev fled to Russia. The elected pro-Akayev parliament nonetheless elected an Akayev opponent as Speaker and called for new presidential elections on June 26. On April 3, Akayev signed his resignation in Moscow, which was notarized in lieu of a constitutional requirement that he present his resignation in person to parliament. Because his safety still could not be guaranteed, due to continued calls for his impeachment, his recorded resignation was to be heard and accepted by a special session of parliament on April 6 and broadcast live.    Opposition against Akayev strengthened with international criticism for election abuses, his government's crackdown on opposition groups and independent media, and his failure to bring those responsible for killing six peaceful demonstrators in 2002 to justice. Poverty and widespread corruption contributed to public anger. Akayev fled to Russia after opposition supporters stormed the main government building and mobs looted parts of Bishkek. He resigned as president in Moscow, with impeachment the alternative. In his address to the nation, Akayev apologized to people who bore him grudges, hoped the presidential election would be democratic, and said he wouldn't fight the new government.    Massive uprisings continued in Kyrgyzstan, fueled by anger over the rigged parliamentary elections. When protesters finally stormed the presidential compound on 30 March, President Akayev fled to Moscow. Two nights of looting and gunfire followed in Bishkek. A delegation headed by the new speaker of Parliament went to Moscow to negotiate with Akayev. Akayev signed his formal resignation at the Kyrgyz Embassy in Moscow on 4 April. His recorded statement was to be shown to Parliament and then broadcast on national television. Presidential elections are now scheduled for 26 June.

summary: Prominent award-winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk was indicted for insulting the Turkish identity by comments he made to a Swiss reporter about one million Armenians massacred in Turkey during World War I. He could face up to three years in prison. The US and EU called on Turkey to drop the charges. His December 16 trial was suspended until February 7 because the court lacked a justice ministry order to proceed. The case has stirred outrage across Europe. EU officials were there to observe the trial, the outcome of which could damage the Turkey's chances of joining the EU.    Prominent Turkish novelist, Orhan Pamuk, was indicted over controversial remarks about the Armenian massacres. Pamuk is charged under Turkey's penal code which carries a jail term of more than three years for a person who "explicitly insults" the Turkish republic. The European Union (EU) warned Turkey that its prosecution of Pamuk could damage its chance of joining the EU and is a test of Turkey's commitment to freedom of expression and reforms in its law. European countries, U.S. and activist organizations have criticized Turkey's lack of democratic principles and citizen's rights.     In a Swiss newspaper interview, Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk said Turkey deliberately killed one million Armenians during WWI, triggering public outrage. He was indicted under Turkey's revised penal code for "public denigration of the Turkish identity," carrying up to 3 years in jail. Turkey says the deaths were fewer and from civil unrest, not genocide. The US, European Union, and activist organizations criticized Turkey's criminal charges for freedom of expression. The EU said Pamuk's trial would affect Turkey's EU bid. A Turkish court ruled Pamuk should be tried under old laws requiring justice ministry direct order and postponed the trial.    Orhan Pamuk went to court on 16 December for outspoken comments made during a Swiss newspaper interview about the Armenian massacres. The EU warned that the trial could affect Turkey's EU accession process because it would indicate the strength of Turkey's commitment to recent reforms guaranteeing freedom of expression. The EU Enlargement Commissioner said, "It is not Orhan Pamuk who will stand trial, but Turkey." The trial was suspended until 7 February pending a decision from the Justice Ministry. The offense had been made before the new penal code had gone into effect and therefore came under the old law.

summary: Turkey was heavily criticized by international human rights groups over Orhan Pamuk's trial. Turkish intellectuals and EU officials demanded that Turkey change the laws that limit freedom of expression. To avoid an EU confrontation, Turkey's justice minister sent Pamuk's case back to the local Istanbul court, which then dropped the charges on a technicality. The EU welcomed the ruling, which came just days before it was to begin a review of Turkey's justice system. Turkey categorically denies Armenian accusations that up to 1.5 million died in a genocide orchestrated by the Ottoman Empire between 1915 and 1917.      A group of 169 Turkish intellectuals asked the government to scrap laws that limit freedom of expression and interfere with Turkey's democratic process. Istanbul's court dropped charges against Pamuk stating that it wasn't legally competent to judge this case. The court was chided for framing the dismissal in bureaucratic terms rather than addressing freedom of expression. About 70 intellectuals have been charged as well, but they don't have the same high profile as Pamuk. The EU pressed Turkey to address legal loopholes limiting freedom of speech in other cases.    Turkey's Justice Ministry declined to rule on whether Pamuk should be tried, citing recent penal code amendments. It sent the case back to the Istanbul court, which dropped the charges against Pamuk. The case divided Turkey and embarrassed its liberals. Pamuk's remarks also highlighted another painful episode in Turkish history, the 30,000 Kurdish deaths in recent guerrilla fighting in Turkey's Kurdish southeast. Turkish intellectuals, the EU, and most of the West called on Turkey's government to scrap laws limiting freedom of expression. Potential EU partners wanted to know that Turkish laws were the same as laws elsewhere in the EU.    The case against Orhan Pamuk ended on 23 January. The Justice Ministry had refused to issue an approval of the prosecution and told the Istanbul court that it should determine whether to proceed. The Istanbul court dropped the charges. Pamuk's lawyer criticized the decision, saying that it was framed in bureaucratic terms and avoided the issue of freedom of expression. Turkish nationalists were outraged. The EU Enlargement Commissioner said that Pamuk was not the only one facing such charges, he was "just the most high-profile case." PEN says that some 70 Turkish intellectuals have been charged with similar offenses.
